PURPOSE OF AWARD: THE GOAL OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT WORK AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUNG ADULTS THROUGH COLLABORATIVE PARTICIPATION IN NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK. COLLECTIVELY THE PROJECTS FOSTER YOUTH INVOLVEMENT IN CRITICAL PROJECTS THAT HELP PRESERVE AND PROTECT THE RESOURCES OF SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK. THESE PROJECTS ALSO PROVIDE VALUABLE EDUCATIONAL AND VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE VISITING PUBLIC INTERESTED IN LEARNING ABOUT OR HELPING TO PROTECT NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: WORK WILL FOCUS ON THE FIELD MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, VISITOR SERVICES, AND CULTURAL RESOURCES PRESERVATION. SPECIFIC PROJECTS INCLUDE FOREST VEGETATION MONITORING, RARE PLANT MONITORING, FISH MONITORING, PEREGRINE FALCON RESTORATION, ROADSIDE WILDLIFE AVERSIVE CONDITIONING, PUBLIC TOURS OF HISTORIC STRUCTURES, AND IMPROVEMENTS TO MUSEUM COLLECTIONS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:IMPLEMENTATION OF FISH, RARE PLANT, AND FOREST MONITORING PROGRAMREMOVAL OF EXOTIC FISH FROM PARK STREAMSREDUCED HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTINTERPRETATION OF CULTURAL SITES FOR VISITORSIMPROVED MUSEUM COLLECTIONSBNEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT PROVIDES HANDS-ON SERVICE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INTERNS THAT WILL HELP DEVELOP A GENERATION OF SKILLED WORKERS IN THE BOTANY, FOREST HEALTH, WILDLIFE, AND MUSEUM CURATION DISCIPLINES. EDUCATING YOUNG PEOPLE WITH DIRECT JOB EXPERIENCES SUCH AS THAT PROVIDED BY THESE INTERNSHIPS, GIVES THEM VALUABLE SKILLS AND PERSPECTIVES THAT HELP THEM BECOME MORE EDUCATED AND ACTIVE CITIZENS, FUTURE LEADERS, AND STEWARDS OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF THE SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK'S NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES AND FROM TRAINING OF EARLY CAREER PROFESSIONALS. THE PARK WILL RECEIVE THE ANCILLARY BENEFIT FROM THE YOUTH'S ASSISTANCE WITH IMPLEMENTING NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND INTERPRETATION.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):GOLDEN SPIKE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK DESIRES TO SPONSOR A 4-5 MEMBER UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY/UTAH CONSERVATION CORPS (UCC) WORK CREW TO ASSIST PARK STAFF IN THE CONTROL OF AGGRESSIVE, HIGH PRIORITY INVASIVE PLANTS IN THIS UNIT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. IN PARTICULAR, RUSH SKELETONWEED IS RAPIDLY EXPANDING ITS CONTROL AT GOLDEN SPIKE NHP AND THE PARK NEEDS TO CONTROL IT AND PREVENT IT FROM EXPANDING TO ITS NEIGHBORING LANDOWNERS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:USU/UCC WILL PROVIDE A 4-5-PERSON YOUNG ADULT CREW FOR 160 HOURS FOR INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL, SEED COLLECTION, AND OTHER NATIVE VEGETATION CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES. THE NPS AND UCC WILL DETERMINE PROJECT TIMELINES AND WORKLOAD, PLAN LOGISTICS, DETERMINE EDUCATION AND TRAINING NEEDS, ETC. THE NORTHERN ROCKY MOUNTAIN INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT TEAM WILL ALSO ASSIST IN TRAINING AND SUPERVISING THIS WORK FORCE IN THE FIELD. SEASONAL FLEXIBILITY THROUGHOUT THE WORK PERIOD ALLOWS FOR CREWS TO PERFORM THE WORK WHEN INVASIVE PLANTS ARE MOST SUSCEPTIBLE TO PREFERRED TREATMENTS AND NATIVE SEEDS ARE ABLE TO BE COLLECTED. USU/UCC WILL PROVIDE ALL MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT FOR WORK AND CAMPING AND PROVIDE TRANSPORTATION TO PARK AND TO INDIVIDUAL WORK SITES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SAFE AND WELL DOCUMENTED INVASIVE PLANT INVENTORIES AND CONTROL TREATMENTS; NATIVE SEEDS COLLECTED AND STOREDBENEFICIARIES:NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY

COMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: N/AFUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: N/AREQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS COLLABORATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION INC, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) WILL ASSIST FORT LARAMIE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE TO PRESERVE, CATALOG, AND DIGITIZE FOR SECURITY AND ACCESS APPROXIMATELY 10,000 MUSEUM AND ARCHIVAL ITEMS. THIS PROJECT HELPS THE PARK MEET CURRENT PRIORITIES SET BY THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR, INCLUDING CREATING A CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP LEGACY THROUGH PRESERVING AND CATALOGING PRECIOUS PARK RESOURCES INTO INTERIOR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (ICMS). ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT ENSURES AGENCY AND PARK GOALS ARE CONTINUED AND MET. THIS NATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT COLLECTION DOCUMENTS A WIDE ARRAY OF RESOURCES AND ACTIVITIES ON THE PREMIER FRONTIER POST OF WESTERN EXPANSION IN THE UNITED STATES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE BASELINE DOCUMENTATION THROUGH DETAILED CATALOG RECORDS IN ICMS THAT WILL ACCURATELY DESCRIBE THE CURRENT INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONDITION OF THE ARTIFACTS AND PROVIDE BASELINE DATA FOR FUTURE MONITORING AND REPORTING. COMPLETED PREVENTATIVE MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES ON NEARLY 10,000 OBJECTS WILL BE PERFORMED THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THE INTERNSHIP.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THERE ARE OVER 350,000 ARTIFACTS IN THE FORT LARAMIE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE MUSEUM. NEARLY 10,000 OF THESE OBJECTS ARE ON EXHIBIT AND DISPLAY TO THE PUBLIC. ACCESSIBILITY TO VIEW THIS MATERIAL AND ENSURE ITS INTEGRITY FOR THE FUTURE RELIES HEAVILY ON THE ACTIONS AND PREVENTATIVE MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY THAT NEEDS TO BE CONDUCTED ANNUALLY. INTERN WILL ASSIST IN THIS PROCESS THROUGH RECEIVING HANDS-ON TRAINING BY EXPERIENCED PROFESSIONALS. ADDITIONALLY, THEY WILL REHOUSE AND INVENTORY ARTIFACTS ENSURING THEY MAINTAIN SCIENTIFIC INTEGRITY FOR FUTURE STUDY AND PUBLIC USE. THE INTERNS WILL CATALOG OBJECTS INTO THE INTERIOR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (ICMS).BENEFICIARIES:THE PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM THIS PROJECT ARE MANY. PUBLIC INTEREST IN NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES IS CONTINUALLY GROWING. OVER 46,000 VISITORS CAME TO FORT LARAMIE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE IN FY 21. NEARLY ALL THESE PATRONS VIEW AND INQUIRE ABOUT OBJECTS ON EXHIBIT WHICH INCLUDE THEIR PROVENANCE TO THE SITE, HISTORICAL CONTEXT, TIES TO FAMILIAL HISTORY, AND MORE. ADDITIONALLY, OBJECTS IN THE COLLECTION ARE USED IN COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECTS WITH UNDERGRADUATE, GRADUATE, AND FACULTY FROM UNIVERSITIES NATIONWIDE, INDEPENDENT AND NEWS MEDIA, AND MANY MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC. ALL CATALOGING AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES SECURE THE PUBLIC'S INTEREST AND ACCESSIBILITY TO THESE MATERIALS. INCREASED INTELLECTUAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROL WILL ALSO IMPROVE SECURITY AND PRESERVATION OF THE MATERIALS, AN INTEGRAL PART OF FORT LARAMIE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITES STRATEGIC GOALS FOR COLLECTIONS HELD IN THE PUBLIC TRUST.

THE PURPOSE OF AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE GOVERNMENT'S OBJECTIVE TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUNG PEOPLE TO LEARN ABOUT ITS HISTORIC PRESERVATION EFFORTS AND GAIN JOB SKILLS BY SPENDING TIME WORKING IN NATIONAL PARKS. THE PROJECT INCLUDES INSTALLING A NEW WALL, SIDING AND FLOORING, PAINTING, BOARDWALK REPAIRS, ETC. THE GOAL IS TO AFFORD LOCAL DIVERSE YOUTH THE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN CONSTRUCTION AND CONSERVATION SKILLS BY USING THE PROJECT TO REFURBISH THE INTERIOR OF THE COTTAGE, AS WELL AS THE BOARDWALK LEADING UP TO THE CABIN. THE PROJECT WILL NOT ONLY BENEFIT THE YOUTH ENGAGED IN THE WORK, BUT ONCE COMPLETED, THE COTTAGE WILL SERVE FOR PUBLIC USE AND PROGRAMMING.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE NPS AND THE RECIPIENT WISH TO COOPERATE IN ENGAGING AND EMPOWERING YOUTH AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO FIND THEIR RELEVANCY IN THE OLMSTED BICENTENNIAL COMMEMORATION THROUGH COLLABORATIVE PROGRAMMING AND PARK EXPERIENCES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO FURTHER DEVELOP COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS WITH EMPHASIS ON YOUTH AUDIENCES, THROUGH A YOUTH INTERNSHIP. SPECIFICALLY, THE NPS AND THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK TOGETHER TO SELECT AND ONBOARD A YOUTH INTERN. THE RESULTING INTERNSHIP WILL WORK WITH STAFF, COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AND YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS TO RESEARCH, CO-DEVELOP, AND CO-FACILITATE ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES ON SITE AND AT LOCAL OLMSTED-DESIGNED LANDSCAPES. THIS PROJECT WILL DRAMATICALLY INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE OLMSTED STORY IN LINE WITH THE GOALS OF THE OLMSTED BICENTENNIAL COMMEMORATION. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A TEMPLATE FOR HOW TO CONTINUE TO MOVE FORWARD IN COMMUNITY AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BEGINNING IN APRIL 2022 (THE MONTH OF THE BICENTENNIAL BIRTHDAY) COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL BE ENGAGED TO BRAINSTORM AND PLAN SHARED PROGRAMMING TO BE OFFERED THROUGHOUT THE REST OF 2022. WORKING WITH THE RECIPIENT, NPS WILL WORK WITH THE SELECTED INTERN TO FACILITATE EFFECTIVE AND PRODUCTIVE COMMUNITY AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT TO OFFER AT LEAST 4 NEWLY DEVELOPED PROGRAMS TO ACTIVATE LOCAL PARK SPACES BY AND FOR THE COMMUNITIES.BENEFICIARIES:THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE COMMUNITIES IN THE SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOODS, SPECIFICALLY YOUTH IN THESE COMMUNITIES, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO WILL GAIN BROADER AWARENESS AND ACCESS TO THE SITE; AS WELL AS AN UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION FOR THE OLMSTED LEGACY ON THEIR LIVES AND COMMUNITIES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD:THIS 21ST CENTURY CONSERVATION SERVICE CORPS (21CSC) PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ONE YOUNG PERSON AN INTERNSHIP POSITION IN THE NATIONAL PARKS OF BOSTON TO ACCOMPLISH MEANINGFUL WORK, AND GAIN IMPORTANT PROFESSIONAL SKILLS WHILE BUILDING A LIFELONG CONNECTION TO THE CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL HERITAGE STEWARDED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. THIS PROJECT HELPS THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE REACH ITS COMMITMENT TO CREATING A DIVERSE AND INCLUSIVE ENVIRONMENT THAT IS RELEVANT AND ACCESSIBLE TO THE YOUNGER GENERATION BY FOCUSING ON NEW DIGITAL MEDIA CONVEYING UNDERREPRESENTED STORIES RESEARCHED AND PRESENTED BY YOUNG PEOPLE,SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:ONE YOUNG AMERICAN WILL BE ENGAGED IN THE FIELD OF PUBLIC HISTORY AND THE DIGITAL HUMANITIES AT THE NATIONAL PARKS OF BOSTON. THIS FULL-TIME INTERNSHIP WILL LAST 52 WEEKS. THE INTERN WILL ASSIST THE DIGITAL HUMANITIES AND INNOVATION TEAM IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE PARK'S DIGITAL FOOTPRINT, INCLUDING WEBSITE CONTENT RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, AND MAINTENANCE, VIDEO PRODUCTION, AND OTHER DIGITAL NEEDS SUCH AS NEW DIGITAL PRESENTATIONS AT OUR VISITOR CENTERS, SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS, AND OTHER WEB BASED FEATURES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:INTERN WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE BY: WORKING DIRECTLY WITH THE PARK'S DIGITAL HUMANITIES AND INNOVATION TEAM ON ALL ASPECTS OF THE PARK'S DIGITAL PUBLIC HISTORY; WORKING WITH INTERNAL OMEKA S PROGRAM AND ASSISTING WITH THE EXPANSION OF DIGITAL CLASSROOM PROJECTS; SECURING RIGHTS AND OPTIMIZED DIGITAL IMAGES OF SOURCE MATERIAL; AIDING IN THE PARK'S APP DEVELOPMENT AS WELL AND ONSITE DIGITAL KIOSKS, DISPLAYS AND OTHER RELATED TECHNOLOGY; BEING RESPONSIBLE FOR WEBSITE CONTENT DEVELOPMENT USING THE PARK'S TROVE OF MATERIALS IN ADDITION TO SUPPLEMENTAL RESEARCH IF NEEDED. TOPICS MAY INCLUDE AMERICA250, FREEDOM AND UNFREEDOM IN 18TH CENTURY BOSTON, AND OTHER PARK RELATED PROJECTS; WORKING WITH INTERPRETIVE STAFF, FACILITATING SESSIONS AT LOCAL UNIVERSITIES AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS, INCLUDING THE BOSTON PUBLIC LIBRARY LECTURE SERIES, PROGRAMS IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE PARK'S EDUCATION, VOLUNTEER, AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT PROGRAM.BENEFICIARIES:THIS 21CSC PROJECT PROVIDES HANDS-ON SERVICE-LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ONE YOUTH TO GAIN WORK SKILLS AS WELL AS TO LEARN ABOUT AND GAIN APPRECIATION FOR CULTURAL RESOURCES AND BECOME STEWARDS OF PUBLIC LANDS. THE INTERNS WILL ENGAGE LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN DIALOGUE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND OUR COLLECTIVE HISTORY, PROMOTING GREATER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION. THE DIGITAL COLLECTION DEVELOPED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE AVAILABLE TO TEACHERS, STUDENTS, PARTNERS, PARK STAFF AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC TO INCREASE AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATION'S CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL HERITAGE.

?PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE REPAIRS TO OVER 50 MILES OF BOUNDARY FENCE AND REPAIRS TO PARK TRAILS. WORK WILL INCLUDE BRUSHING OVERGROWN VEGETATION FROM TRAILS AND ROADSIDES, DOCUMENTING TRESPASS SITES ALONG PARK BOUNDARIES, REPAIRING FENCE, CLEARING DOWNED TREES, AND REBUILDING FENCE WHERE NECESSARY. TRAIL WORK WILL INCLUDE: RETAINING WALL REPAIR, SMOOTHING AND GRADING OF WALING SURFACES, BRUSHING OVERGROWN VEGETATION, STUMP REMOVAL, REPAIRING AND BUILDING WATER DIVERSION DEVICES, AND OTHER VARIOUS TASKS RELATED TO TRAIL CONSTRUCTION. THROUGHOUT THIS PROJECT THE YOUTH CORPS WILL BE TRAINED IN THE VARIOUS SKILLS AND TASKS IT TAKES TO COMPLETE SUCH PROJECTS. EDUCATION WILL NOT BE LIMITED TO THE TRAILS AND FENCING TRADE, BUT ALSO INCLUDE TIME WITH THE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM DISCUSSING INVASIVE SPECIES, HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, AND THE UNIQUE GEOLOGY AND ECOLOGY PRESENT AT FLAGSTAFF NATIONAL MONUMENTS. CULTURAL RESOURCES STAFF WILL ALSO MEET WITH THE CREW TO DISCUSS THE PRE-HISTORY AND HISTORIC PERIODS THAT SHAPE THE WAY WE VIEW FLAGSTAFF NATIONAL MONUMENTS AND THE SURROUNDING AREAS. LAW ENFORCEMENT AND INTERPRETIVE RANGERS WILL ALSO MEET WITH THE CREWS TO DISCUSS THEIR CAREERS WITH THE NPS AND THE IMPACTS THEY MAKE DAY-TO-DAY.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:COMPLETION OF THE 1- MILE ADA COMPLIANT LOMAKI TRAIL AT WUPATKI NATIONAL MONUMENTREHABILITATION OF THE WALNUT CANYON RIM TRAILPRELIMINARY REHAB OF THE CITADEL TRAIL AT WUPATKI NATIONAL MONUMENTREPAIR OF COMPROMISED BOUNDARY FENCE AT WALNUT CANYON, WUPATKI, AND SUNSET CRATER NATIONAL MONUMENTSREMOVAL OF ROADSIDE AND TRAIL-SIDE VEGETATIONPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:   AT THE COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT:50 MILES OF PARK BOUNDARY FENCE WILL BE REPAIREDFOUR MILES OF PARK TRAILS WILL BE REHABILITATEDROADSIDE AND TRAIL VEGETATION WILL BE REMOVED TO ALLOW FOR UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW SHED FROM ROADS AND TRAILS.BENEFICIARIES:      BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK WILL BE YOUTH AND THE VISITING PUBLIC TO FLAGSTAFF NATIONAL MONUMENT.

COMMUNITIES, WETLAND RESTORATION,      RARE PLANT CONSERVATION, NATIVE SEED COLLECTION, AND AQUATIC RESOURCE      MONITORING.PROVIDE INSTRUCTION AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES FOR ONE INTERN AS      HE/SHE ASSISTS WITH GIS PROJECTS, INCLUDING COLLECTING SPATIAL DATA ABOUT      PARK FACILITIES AND RESOURCES, PRODUCING MAPS, UPDATING GIS DATABASES, AND      CONDUCTING SPATIAL ANALYSIS TO HELP SOLVE MANAGEMENT PROBLEMS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:IMPROVE VISITOR SERVICES AND EXPERIENCES AT THREE PARK VISITOR CENTERS AND SEVERAL OTHER VISITOR CONTACT POINTS.IMPROVE CONTENT OF INFORMATION KIOSKS LOCATED IN THREE PARKS.INCREASE CAPACITY TO DELIVER HIGH-QUALITY INFORMATION AND PRESENTATIONS TO PARK VISITORS.IMPROVE NATURAL RESOURCE CONDITIONS THROUGH RESTORATION, INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL, AND FOREST PEST MANAGEMENT.IMPROVE SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL RESOURCES THROUGH MONITORING, DATA COLLECTION, AND DATA ANALYSIS.IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF (1) LOCATIONS OF PARK INFRASTRUCTURE AND RESOURCES AND (2) SPATIAL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN PARK RESOURCES AND WITHIN PROJECT AREAS.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT PROVIDES HANDS-ON AND REWARDING SERVICE OPPORTUNITIES FOR EIGHT YOUTH THAT WILL HELP DEVELOP A GENERATION OF SKILLED WORKERS, EDUCATED AND ACTIVE CITIZENS, FUTURE LEADERS, AND STEWARDS OF NATURAL RESOURCES. THE YOUTH ACTIVITIES INCREASE EDUCATIONAL AND ACTIVITY-ORIENTED PARK PROGRAMS THAT WILL ENHANCE VISITOR EXPERIENCES AND INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, AND SUPPORT FOR STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATION'S PUBLIC LANDS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT:THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FUND A YOUNG ADULT TRAIL CREW FOR A PERIOD OF 6 WEEKS DEVOTED TO THE MAINTENANCE OF GLACIER BAY NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE'S TWO SEPARATE TRAIL SYSTEMS, ADDRESSING THEIR CHRONIC ISSUES. THE PROJECT WILL BASE CAMP THE CREW IN THE PARK'S BARTLETT COVE CAMPGROUND FOR 3 WEEKS. WHILE IN BARTLETT COVE, THE CREW WILL BE BRUSHING OVERGROWN VEGETATION, REPAIRING TRAIL TREAD AND REPLACING NATIVE TIMBER TRAIL STRUCTURES ON HIGH VISITOR USE HIKING TRAILS, THE CAMPGROUND AND OTHER MAINTAINED LANDSCAPES. THE CREW WILL ALSO BASE CAMP IN DRY BAY FOR A 3 WEEK HITCH TO MAINTAIN THE DRY BAY OHV TRAILS. WHILE IN DRY BAY, THE CREW WILL BE BRUSHING OVERGROWN TRAILS TO PROPER SIGHT DISTANCES FOR VISITOR SAFETY AND REPAIRING DAMAGED TRAIL TREAD.A TEAM OF 4 MEMBERS WITH 1 LEADER WILL WORK ON PROJECTS, BASED OUT OF GUSTAVUS AND DRY BAY. 6-WEEKS OF FIELD WORK. THE TEAM WILL NEED TO BE EXPERIENCED AND WILL SPEND 3-WEEKS IN DRY BAY AND 3-WEEKS IN BARTLETT COVE. BRUCE MCDONOUGH IS THE MAIN CONTACT FOR THE CREW: 907-697-2639. THE TEAM WILL FLY TO GUSTAVUS VIA ALASKA AIRLINES FROM ANCHORAGE, AK. THEY WILL NEED TO CHARTER FLIGHTS AND SUPPLIES INTO DRY BAY USING AN AIR TAXI SERVICE. TEAM WILL ATTEND TRAINING OUTSIDE OF ANCHORAGE WHERE MEMBERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN WILDERNESS FIRST AID CERTIFICATION, BEAR SPRAY TRAINING AND USAGE, CHAINSAW TRAINING AND SCA'S WORK SKILLS TRAINING TO DEVELOP SAFE EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION TECHNIQUES.PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BRING A YOUNG ADULT TRAIL CREW TO GLACIER BAY FOR A MINIMUM OF 6 WEEKS DEVOTED TO THE MAINTENANCE OF TWO SEPARATE TRAIL SYSTEMS, ADDRESSING THEIR CHRONIC ISSUES. THE GOAL IS TO ENHANCE VISITOR SAFETY AND IMPROVE VISITOR SATISFACTION, WHILE GAINING VALUABLE WORK EXPERIENCE IN A UNIQUE AND CHALLENGING ENVIRONMENT. PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE FOR THE SCA CREW TO PERFORM MAINTENANCE ON GLACIER BAY NATIONAL PARK'S TRAIL SYSTEM AND HIGH VISITOR USE AREAS WHILE GAINING JOB SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE THROUGH:SAFELY AND EFFECTIVELY OPERATE HAND AND POWER TOOLS TO TRIM AND REMOVE OVERGROWN VEGETATION FOR HIGH VISITOR USE AREAS.SAFELY AND EFFECTIVELY OPERATE HAND AND POWER TOOLS TO REPAIR AND RESTORE TRAIL SURFACES WITH GRAVELS AND NATIVE MATERIALS.SAFELY AND EFFECTIVELY OPERATE HAND AND POWER TOOLS TO REPAIR AND RESTORE TRAIL STRUCTURES WITH NATIVE TIMBER.WORK EFFICIENTLY TOGETHER AS A TEAM TO ACCOMPLISH SHARED GOALS AND OBJECTIVES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PERFORMANCEGOALS -THE SELECTED INTERNS (11) WILL COMPLETE AWEEK LONGORIENTATION AND TRAINING DURING SPRING BREAK AND 8-16 WEEK SUMMER INTERNSHIPS IN A VARIETY OF DISCIPLINES RELATING TO THE OPERATIONS, STEWARDSHIP AND PROTECTION OF NATIONAL PARKS. ACE WILL BE A PRIMARY PARTNER IN TRAINING, RECRUITING, AND PLACING INTERNS.PROJECT OBJECTIVES:INTERNS WILL BE PLACED INTO POSITIONS WITH 6 PROGRAMS WITHING THE PARK: INTERPRETATION, TRAILS, FIRE EFFECTS, PHYSICAL SCIENCE, VISITOR & RESOURCE PROTECTION, AND SOCIAL SCIENCE. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROVIDE A LEARNING OPPORTUNITY FOR INTERNS WHILE ACHIEVING THE GOALS FOR EACH DIVISION OR PROGRAM.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:INTERNS WILL ATTEND A WEEK-LONG TRAINING AND PARTICIPATE IN 8-16 WEEK SUMMER INTERNSHIPS. ACTIVITIES DIFFER BY POSITION AND WILL INVOLVE WORKING ALONGSIDE PARK STAFF TO COMPLETE DUTIES AND ACHIEVE PARK GOALS. INTERN ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: PROVIDING INTERPRETATION TO PARK VISITORS, COMPLETING TRAIL WORK, STUDYING FIRE EFFECTS, COLLECTING SCIENTIFIC DATA, AND PROMOTING VISITOR SAFETY.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:INTERNS WILL COMPLETE A WEEK-LONG SPRING ORIENTATION AND BEGIN WORK DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. INTERNS WILL RECEIVE TRAINING UPON ARRIVAL AT THEIR JOBS AND THROUGHOUT THE SEASON. BY THE END OF THE SEASONS INTERNS WILL HAVE LEARNED NEW SKILLS, GAINED NEW EXPERIENCES, AND HELPED ACHIEVE THE GOALS OF THE DIVISION THEY WORK FOR. BENEFICIARIES:BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE INTERNS, PARK STAFF, THE PARK RESOURCE, AND THE AMERICAN PUBLIC.

STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION FIRE CREWS WILL ASSIST THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, INTERIOR REGIONS 8, 9, 10, AND 12 (FORMERLY PACIFIC WEST REGION) FIRE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM WITH FUELS TREATMENT ACTIVITIES AT VARIOUS PARK UNITS. THE FIRE CREWS WILL GAIN HANDS ON EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING TO PURSUE CAREERS IN FIRE MANAGEMENT. FIRE CREWS WILL ASSIST WITH VEGETATION MANAGEMENT AND HAZARD FUELS REDUCTION INCLUDING HANDLINE CONSTRUCTION, CHAINSAW LIMBING AND FELLING, CHAINSAW CUTTING OF BRUSH AND SHRUBS, HANDPILING OF DEBRIS, WORKING WITH MECHANICAL CHIPPERS, OPERATING WEED WHIP AND HAND OPERATED MOWING DEVICES, AND CREATING DEFENSIBLE SPACE AROUND STRUCTURES AND DEVELOPED PUBLIC USE AREAS. CREWS WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH PRESCRIBED FIRE ACTIVITIES SUCH AS HANDLINE CONSTRUCTION, HAND IGNITION OF PILES, BROADCAST FIRE MANAGEMENT HAND IGNITIONS AND FIRE CONTROL LINE HOLDING ACTIVITIES.PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL HELP TO INCREASE THE PACE AND SCALE OF ACCOMPLISHING FUEL TREATMENT WORK WITHIN THE REGION, AND HELP TO CREATE RESILIENT LANDSCAPES, FIRE ADAPTED LOCAL COMMUNITIES, AND IMPROVE RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES THE CREWS WILL COMPLETE WILL HELP REDUCE THE RISKS OF CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE SPREADING THROUGHOUT NATIONAL PARK SERVICE UNITS AND HELP TO PROTECT AND RESTORE THE VALUED NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE THE YOUTH AND VETERANS EMPLOYED THROUGH THIS PROGRAM AS WELL AS LOCAL COMMUNITIES.

COMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: N/A FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: N/A REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT INTERNSHIP PROMOTES STEWARDSHIP OF RESOURCES BY YOUTH FOR THE PUBLIC BENEFIT AND FACILITATES "HANDS ON" FIELD EXPERIENCES THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE PROTECTION AND UNDERSTANDING OF PARK BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION INTERN WILL ASSIST THE PARK BIOLOGIST WITH INVASIVE TREE REMOVAL FROM HISTORICAL PASTURES OF THE FORKED LIGHTNING RANCH OF PECOS NHP. INVASIVE JUNIPER AND PINE SEEDLINGS WILL BE REMOVED SO THAT HISTORIC PASTURES CAN BE RESTORED, AND VISITORS CAN ENJOY NATIVE GRASSLANDS AND ASSOCIATED WILDLIFE VIEWING AND INTERPRETIVE OPPORTUNITIES. WORK ASSOCIATED WITH THIS WILL INVOLVE A VARIETY OF TASKS. REMOVAL OF TREES WILL INVOLVE THE USE OF CHAINSAWS, HANDSAWS, OR BATTERY-OPERATED RECIPROCATING SAWS. THE INTERN WILL ASSIST WITH REMOVAL OF SLASH TO NEARBY ROADS OR ERODING ARROYOS. SLASH WILL BE MOVED TO THESE AREAS USING SLINGS OR WHEELBARROWS. THE INTERN WILL ALSO ASSIST MOVING SLASH WITH UTVS, TRUCKS, AND TRAILERS TO DESIGNATED DUMPSTER AND CHIPPING. THE INTERN WILL ASSIST WITH THE OPERATION OF A WOODCHIPPER.THERE ARE SOME POPULATIONS OF EXOTIC PLANTS THAT ARE REDUCING BIODIVERSITY OF PASTURE GRASSLANDS. THE INTERN WILL ASSIST WITH.NON-NATIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT PROJECTS USING CHEMICAL, MECHANICAL, AND MANUAL METHODS. REMOVAL OF NON-NATIVE PLANTS WILL PROMOTE THE SPREAD OF NATIVE RHIZOMATOUS GRASSES AND NATIVE FORBES, ENCOURAGING THE RETURN OF WILDLIFE (ELK, DEER, BUTTERFLIES, ETC.) TO THE AREA. CHEMICAL METHODS INCLUDE SPRAYING HERBICIDE WITH BACKPACK SPRAYERS. MECHANICAL METHODS INCLUDE USING WEED EATERS AND BRUSH-CUTTERS. MANUAL METHODS INCLUDE HAND PULLING AND THE USE OF OTHER HAND TOOLS. STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION INTERN WILL DOCUMENT ALL WORK PERFORMED WITH GPS UNITS, PHOTOGRAPHY, DATA SHEETS, AND FIELD JOURNALS.THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION INTERN WILL LEARN VALUABLE PLANT IDENTIFICATION SKILLS.THE STUDENT CONSERVATION INTERN WILL ASSIST WITH ANY OTHER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT RELATED PROJECTS DETERMINED BY THE PARK BIOLOGIST INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO: WILDLIFE SOUND RECORDERS, WILDLIFE CAMERAS, PLANT INVENTORIES, TREE CAGING MAINTENANCE, ETC. THERE WILL BE NUMEROUS OPPORTUNITIES TO EXPLORE DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE PARK THROUGHOUT THE SEASON. INTERNS WILL BE TRAINED IN UTV USE, VEHICLE USE, CHIPPER SAFETY, SAW SAFETY, NON-NATIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT, GPS, MONITORING, AND DOCUMENTATION. IN ADDITION, THEY WILL BE TRAINED IN BACKCOUNTRY, EQUIPMENT, AND HERBICIDE SAFETY AND ORIENTATED TO NPS MANAGEMENT AND PHILOSOPHY.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:HELP PARK STAFF COMPLETE SEVERAL NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION PROJECTS BY THE END OF THE SUMMER.BENEFICIARIES: YOUTH OR INTERNS INTERESTED IN GOVERNMENT WORK/CONSERVATION.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE UTAH CONSERVATION CORPS WILL HELP THE PARK PROTECT SENSITIVE VEGETATION AND SOILS FROMVISITOR IMPACTS BY INSTALLING BARRIERS ALONG WALKWAYS AND TRAILS. CREWS WILL ALSO REHABILITATESENSITIVE AREAS THAT HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY VISITORS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:CREWS WILL INSTALL WOODEN RAIL FENCE ALONG BUSY WALKWAYS TO KEEP VISITORS ON ESTABLISH PATHS.ONCE AREAS ARE ADEQUATELY PROTECTED, THEY WILL REHABILITATE COMPACTED SOIL, INSTALL EROSIONCONTROL FEATURES, AND HELP REESTABLISH NATIVE PLANTS IN IMPACTED AREAS BY PLANTING SEED ANDSALVAGED NATIVE SPECIES. CREWS WILL ALSO INSTALL SIGNS THAT WILL HELP INFORM VISITORS OF IMPACTSTO RESOURCES IN SENSITIVE AREAS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN CONSTRUCTED RAIL FENCE ALONG THE RIM TRAIL PAVED WALKWAY BETWEENSUNRISE AND SUNSET POINTS AND ALONG ACCESS PATHS FROM PARKING LOTS AND THE LODGE AREA. IT WILLALSO RESULT IN THE REDUCTION OF SOCIAL TRAILS IN NATURAL AREAS AND THE INCREASE IN REHABILITATEDVEGETATION.BENEFICIARIES:THE VISITING PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PRESERVATION OF NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES. THIS WILLCONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL HEALTH OF THE ECOSYSTEMS OF BRYCE CANYON AND IMPROVE VISITOREXPERIENCES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO RECRUIT THREE INTERNS TO BE MEMBERS OF THE CAPITOL REEF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT TEAM EACH SEASON. ONE INTERN WILL SERVE AS A BOTANIST FOR THE PARK RARE PLANT MONITORING TEAM. ONE INTERN WILL BE THE LEAD SOCIAL SCIENTIST FOR PARK PLANNING EFFORTS. A THIRD INTERN WILL ASSIST THE PARK BIOLOGIST WITH REVEGETATION PROJECTS AND NEEDS. THE INTERNS AND STAFF FROM CAPITOL REEF NATIONAL PARK (CARE) WILL COLLABORATE TO USE STANDARDIZED PROTOCOLS TO COLLECT, ORGANIZE, ANALYZE AND REPORT ON DATA IN THEIR RESPECTIVE SUBJECT AREAS. ANOTHER GOAL IS TO PROVIDE THE INTERNS WITH A VARIETY OF NATURAL RESOURCES EXPERIENCES. THEREFORE, THE INTERNS MAY ALSO ASSIST THE PARK'S RESOURCE MANAGEMENT STAFF WITH REVEGETATION PROJECTS, SPOTTED OWL AND PEREGRINE FALCON SURVEYS, VISITOR USE MONITORING, INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL AND MONITORING CAMERA TRAPS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:RESPECTIVELY, THE INTERNS WILL 1) CONDUCT RARE PLANT SURVEYS AND COLLECT DATA FROM DEMOGRAPHIC PLOTS (BOTANY INTERN), 2) COLLECT VISITOR USE DATA, CONDUCT VISITOR USE SURVEYS, AND ORGANIZE AND SUMMARIZE DATA IN THE OFFICE (SOCIAL SCIENCE INTERN), AND 3) COLLECT AND CONSERVE NATIVE PLANT SEED, MAP RESTORATION NEEDS, AND REPORT ON DATA COLLECTION (REVEGETATION INTERN). IN THE OFFICE, DATA WILL BE DOWNLOADED FROM GPS UNITS INTO AN ARCGIS GEODATABASE OR MANUALLY ENTERED. EACH INTERN WILL DO QUALITY CONTROL CHECKS OF THE DATA AND DEVELOP SUMMARY REPORTS FOR THEIR RESPECTIVE AREAS. THE BOTANY INTERN WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR MENTORING AND PROVIDING GUIDANCE TO OTHER MEMBERS OF THE BOTANY TEAM ENSURING THAT STANDARDIZED PROTOCOLS ARE FOLLOWED WHEN COLLECTING AND MANAGING FIELD DATA. THE SOCIAL SCIENCE INTERN WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR COORDINATING WORK WITH PARK STAFF AND OUTSIDE EXPERTS THAT ASSURES HIGH QUALITY DATA COLLECTION TO SERVE PARK PLANNING NEEDS. THE REVEGETATION INTERN WITH BE RESPONSIBLE FOR NATIVE SEED COLLECTION AND DOCUMENTATION, MAPPING RESTORATION AND SEED COLLECTION AREAS, AND COORDINATING WITH THE PARK BIOLOGIST TO ASSURE TIMELY PROJECT REVEGETATION.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE PRIMARY GOAL IS TO PROVIDE EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF YOUNG ADULTS THROUGH HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE COLLECTING SCIENTIFIC DATA IN THE FIELD AND ORGANIZING AND SUMMARIZING DATA IN THE OFFICE. BY COMPLETING PROJECTS IN THEIR RESPECTIVE AREAS, THE INTERNS WILL ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES FOR THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE: THE RARE PLANT WORK WILL CONTRIBUTE NEW KNOWLEDGE THAT WILL BE USED BY RESEARCHERS AND BIOLOGISTS FROM AGENCIES BEYOND THE NPS. THE SOCIAL SCIENCE WORK WILL BUILD THE PARK KNOWLEDGE BASE FOR VISITOR USE PLANNING DECISION AS WELL AS PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO VISITOR USE IN AREAS OUTSIDE OF CARE. THE REVEGETATION WORK WILL FILL A CRITICAL NEED WITH UPCOMING PROJECTS AS WELL AS HELPING TO BUILD A PARK VEGETATION MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.BENEFICIARIES:THE INTERNS WILL GAIN VALUABLE EXPERIENCE AS PROFESSIONALS IN A BUSY NATIONAL PARK SERVICE PARK-BASED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. THE NPS WILL ACHIEVE STRATEGIC DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS, AND SUMMARIES AS WELL AS A ROBUST REVEGETATION EFFORT FOR FUTURE ROAD PROJECTS.

THE RECIPIENT WILL SELECT AND OVERSEE QUALIFIED AND MOTIVATED UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TO WORK ALONGSIDE NPS STAFF IN THE CULTURAL RESOURCES, INTERPRETATION, AND RELATED FIELDS IN DIFFERENT PARK UNITS/PROGRAMS AND FEDERAL OFFICES THROUGHOUT THE NATION. INTERNS AND FELLOWS WILL PERFORM RESEARCH AND WILL COLLECT SUCH HISTORY UNCOVERED BY PARKS, REGIONS, AND PROGRAMS INTO NATIONALLY RELEVANT STORIES. THEIR WORK WILL EXPAND THE STORIES OF CHANGE AND CONTINUITY ON THE HOMEFRONT TO TELL ALL AMERICANS' STORIES. INTERNS AND FELLOWS WILL COMMUNICATE WITH THE FIELD AND RELEVANT PARTNERS AND SCHOLARS, COLLECT RESEARCH AND PROJECT STORIES, CONDUCT RESEARCH, CREATE NATIONAL CONTEXT(S), AND CREATE DIGITAL CONTENT TO SHARE THE INFORMATION OUT MORE BROADLY, SUCH AS SHARED CONTENT ON NPS.GOV, INCLUDING TELLING ALL AMERICANS' STORIES SUBJECT SITE AND ASSOCIATED SITES, CONTENT FOR TEACHING WITH HISTORIC PLACES, DISCOVER OUR SHARED HERITAGE TRAVEL SITE, AND POTENTIALLY OTHER PRODUCTS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOCUS ON YOUTH ENGAGEMENT IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, EDUCATION, AND JOB TRAINING THROUGH MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH VEGETATIVE ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT AT GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: VEGETATION MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: NATIVE SEED COLLECTION, PLANT SALVAGE, PLANT SURVEYS, PLANT POPULATION DATA MAPPING, DATA COLLECTION AND MONITORING, AND OVERALL SUPPORT OF THE NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS PROGRAM AT GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A SHARED ACHIEVEMENT OF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT SKILL DEVELOPMENT IN AMERICA'S YOUTH BY PERFORMING FIELD-BASED VEGETATION MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. AN EMPHASIS OF QUALITY OF QUANTITY WILL BE ENCOURAGED. AS SUCH, MILESTONES OF QUANTITY OF SEED COLLECTED OR ACREAGE MAPPED ARE NOT PERTINENT.BENEFICIARIES: THE PUBLIC, AMERICA'S YOUTH, GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK LAND MANAGERS, AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITY MEMBERS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD:THIS AGREEMENT IS BETWEEN THE FIRE MANAGEMENT AND ECOLOGY GROUP FOR THE NPS AT BAND IN NM, AND CONSERVATION LEGACY. WE ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO STIMULATE WORK, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR US CITIZENS. OUR AGREEMENT WILL CREATE JOBS IN THE AMERICAN ECONOMY BY PROVIDING EMPLOYMENT TO INDIVIDUALS WHO WILL UTILIZE SCIENCE TO IDENTIFY BEST PRACTICES TO MANAGE LAND AND WATER RESOURCES AND ADAPT TO CHANGES IN THE ENVIRONMENT - MORE SPECIFICALLY, THE WILDLAND FIRE ENVIRONMENT.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:OUR FIRE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IS FOCUSED ON REDUCING HAZARDOUS FUELS AND EXTREME FIRE BEHAVIOR IN SOUTHWESTERN FORESTS BY IMPLEMENTING FUEL TREATMENTS SUCH AS MECHANICAL THINNING AND PRESCRIBED FIRE. WE MONITOR AND STUDY THE EFFECTS OF THE MECHANICAL THINNING AND PRESCRIBED FIRE TREATMENTS, AND USE THIS INFORMATION TO DETERMINE 1) IF FIRE AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES, SUCH AS REDUCING THE POTENTIAL FOR EXTREME FIRE BEHAVIOR IN THE WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE (WUI), ARE BEING MET 2) TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF FIRE AND THINNING PRESCRIPTIONS 3) TO DETERMINE IF IMPROVEMENTS CAN BE MADE OR IF ADDITIONAL RESEARCH IS NEEDED. WE ALSO MONITOR THE EFFECTS OF WILDFIRE ON THE VEGETATION AND FUELS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PARTICIPATING IN SAFETY BRIEFINGS DETAILING THE LOCAL POTENTIAL SAFETY ISSUES AND HAZARDS (E.G. LIGHTNING, RATTLESNAKES), WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON DEHYDRATION, EXHAUSTION, AND THE IMPORTANCE OF REST AND TAKING BREAKSASSISTING IN INSTALLING VEGETATION AND FUEL PLOTS AND COLLECTING ECOLOGICAL FIELD DATAUSING A GPS FOR LOCATION AND NAVIGATIONASSISTING WITH ENTERING, CHECKING, MANAGING, AND ANALYZING FIELD DATAUSING GIS FOR MAPPING PLOT LOCATIONS AND CREATING PLOT LOCATION MAPSCOMMUNICATING DATA RESULTS TO PARK STAFF TRAVELING TO WORK SITES: ELMA, SALINAS PUEBLO, VALL, AND THE SANTA FE NATIONAL FORESTWORKING WITH OTHER DIVISIONS IN BAND, SUCH AS INTERPRETATION AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENTLEARNING LOCAL PLANTS, HOW TO USE PLANT IDENTIFICATION GUIDES, AND CONTRIBUTING TO PLANT BOOKS CREATED BY THE FIRE ECOLOGY PROGRAMOPPORTUNITIES TO WORK ON LOCAL PRESCRIBED FIRES TO COLLECT DATA RELATED TO SPREAD RATE, FLAME LENGTH, FLAME HEIGHT, SMOKE, AND OTHER FIRE BEHAVIOR ELEMENTS FOR PRESCRIBED BURNSOPPORTUNITY TO MONITOR WEATHER AND COLLECT WEATHER DATA, SUCH AS TEMPERATURE, RELATIVE HUMIDITY, WIND SPEED AND DIRECTION, FOR PRESCRIBED BURNS AND/OR WILDFIRESPARTICIPATING IN PUBLIC OUTREACH EVENTS WITH LOCAL SCHOOL CHILDRENBENEFICIARIES:INTERNS WILL BENEFIT IN THE FOLLOWING WAYS:OPPORTUNITY TO RECEIVE WILDLAND FIREFIGHTER TRAINING AND WORK ON LOCAL PRESCRIBED FIRESFIRST AID/CPR, ARCGIS PRO, AND R SOFTWARE TRAINING AVAILABLEOPPORTUNITY TO ANALYZE, REPORT, AND PRESENT COMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: N/AFUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: N/AREQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD:THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION WILL PROVIDE THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE- TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENT WITH ONE 6-MONTH INTERN. THE INTERN WILL PARTICIPATE IN INTERPRETATION AT THE LOWER CLIFF DWELLING, ADVANCE POST-FIRE RESTORATION PROJECT GOALS, AND MONITOR AND PROTECT ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE INTERN WILL ASSIST TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENT STAFF IN PARK OPERATIONS AND PROJECT WORK. THE INTERN WILL ASSIST PARK STAFF WITH THE POST WOODBURY FIRE ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION PROJECT, INCLUDING REVEGETATION, WORKING WITH VOLUNTEERS, MONITORING VEGETATION PLOTS, AND REMOVING INVASIVE SPECIES. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE MANAGES APPROXIMATELY 13.2 MILLION ACRES OF LAND, RANGING FROMTHE MENTASTA RANGE SOUTH TO THE GULF OF ALASKA, AND FROM THE WRANGELL MOUNTAINS EAST TO ALASKA/CANADABORDER.YOU WILL ASSIST THE PARK'S EDUCATION SPECIALIST WITH A NUMBER OF YOUTH OUTDOOR PROGRAMS IN THE COPPER RIVERBASIN. YOU WILL ALSO PREPARE REPORTS AND ENTER DATA RELATED TO VISITOR USE AND EDUCATIONALMANAGEMENT PROGRAM OBJECTIVES (10%). HOUSING MAY BE ALONE IN A RUSTIC PARK BUNK HOUSE, OR POSSIBLY WITHONE OTHER SEASONAL OF THE SAME SEX WITH ACCESS TO LAUNDRY AND KITCHEN FACILITIES.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:P-P-YOUTH-22-005CFDA(S):15.931APPLICANT NAME:NATIONAL COUNCIL FOR PRESERVATION EDUCATIONDESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT'S PROJECT:NCPE INTERNSHIPS AT KLONDIKE GOLD RUSH NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARKPROJECT ABSTRACT:THE RECIPIENT WILL SELECT AND OVERSEE QUALIFIED AND MOTIVATED UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TO WORK ALONGSIDE NPS STAFF IN THE CULTURAL RESOURCES, INTERPRETATION, AND RELATED FIELDS IN DIFFERENT PARK UNITS/PROGRAMS AND FEDERAL OFFICES THROUGHOUT THE NATION.INTERNS WILL ASSIST STAFF IMPLEMENTING APPROPRIATE ARCHIVES AND CONSERVATION TREATMENT, PROVIDING LONG-TERM STORAGE CONDITIONS, AND DIGITAL DATA PROCESSING. INTERNS WILL COMPLETE TASKS OUTLINED IN THE SCOPE OF WORK.

WITH PROVIDED TRAINING, YOU WILL RESEARCH, PREPARE, AND PRESENT FORMAL AND INFORMAL INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS INCLUDING TALKS AND GUIDED WALKS. YOU WILL BE WORKING IN THE INTERPRETATION & EDUCATION DIVISION OF WRANGELL-ST. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE IN THE KENNECOTT MINES NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARK. YOU WILL WORK AT A VISITOR CENTER DESK TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE AND ORIENTATION FOR PARK VISITORS, PROVIDE WILDERNESS TRIP PLANNING, ANSWER PHONES. YOU WILL CONDUCT ROVING INTERPRETATION IN THE KENNECOTT TOWN SITE AND ON PARK TRAILS. RESEARCHING, DEVELOPING AND PRESENTING INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS, SUCH AS WALKS AND TALKS, ARE A PART OF YOUR DAILY ROUTINE.

COMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: THE GOALS OF THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY ARE TO PARTNER WITH AN AGENCY TO PERFORM YOUTH CAREER DEVELOPMENT VIA VEGETATION MANAGEMENT AT GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK.REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOCUS ON YOUTH ENGAGEMENT IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, EDUCATION, JOB TRAINING, AND FURTHERING THE UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES THROUGH MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH VEGETATIVE ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT AT GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: VEGETATION MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES MAY INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: NATIVE SEED COLLECTION, PLANT SALVAGE, PLANT SURVEYS, INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, PLANT POPULATION DATA MAPPING, DATA COLLECTION AND MONITORING, AND ANY OTHER VEGETATION RELATED MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A SHARED ACHIEVEMENT OF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT SKILL DEVELOPMENT IN AMERICA'S YOUTH BY PERFORMING FIELD-BASED VEGETATION MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. AN EMPHASIS OF QUALITY OF QUANTITY WILL BE ENCOURAGED. AS SUCH, MILESTONES OF QUANTITY OF SEED COLLECTED OR ACREAGE OF INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL ARE NOT PERTINENT.BENEFICIARIES: THE PUBLIC, AMERICA'S YOUTH, GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK LAND MANAGERS, AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITY MEMBERS.

THE UTAH CONSERVATION CREW (UCC) WILL ASSIST PARK STAFF IN IMPROVING WIRE FENCE ALONG SECTIONS OF BOUNDARY ADJACENT TO DIXIE NATIONAL FOREST (DNF) GRAZING ALLOTMENTS. BOTH SMOOTH AND BARBED WIRE WILDLIFE APPROVED FENCING MATERIALS WILL BE USED.CREW WILL INSTALL A WILDLIFE APPROVED 4 WIRE FENCE RECOMMENDS A MAXIMUM WIRE HEIGHT OF 42 INCHES WITH THE BOTTOM WIRE BETWEEN 16 AND 20 INCHES OFF THE GROUND TO ALLOW PRONGHORN AND DEER FAWNS TO GO UNDER. THE TOP AND BOTTOM WIRES SHOULD BE SMOOTH WIRE. THE FENCE DESIGN WILL ALSO INCLUDE THREE WILDLIFE REFLECTORS TAGS.PROVIDE A VALUABLE OPPORTUNITY FOR YOUNG ADULTS INTERESTED IN PUBLIC LAND MANAGEMENT TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE RESTORATION AND PRESERVATION OF WILDLIFE. REMOVE THE TOP AND BOTTOM BARBED WIRES AND REPLACE THEM WITH SMOOTH WIRE TO HELP PROTECT CROSSING WILDLIFE. ATTACH TWO WILDLIFE WARNING REFLECTORS TO THE TOP TWO WIRE TO ASSIST IN PROTECTING CROSSING WILDLIFE.THE WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED WITH BRCA, ESPECIALLY THE UNGULATE SPECIES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE PARK MITIGATE HAZARDOUS TREES THAT POSE A THREAT TO SAFETY AND PROPERTYALONG PARK ROADS AND IN DEVELOPED AREAS OF BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK. CREWS FROM THEAMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE WILL ASSIST PARK RESOURCE MANAGERS WITH CREATING A SAFEENVIRONMENT FOR VISITORS AND STAFF WHILE GAINING VALUABLE SKILLS IN TREE FALLING AND HAZARDRECOGNITION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:CREWS WILL ASSIST PARK RESOURCE MANAGERS WITH SCHEDULED ANNUAL EVALUATION AND REMOVAL OF TREESTHAT POSE A RISK TO HEALTH, SAFETY, AND PROPERTY. CREWS WILL EVALUATE TREES FOR POTENTIAL THREATSBASED ON CRITERIA PROVIDED BY PARK RESOURCE MANAGERS. CRITERIA WILL INCLUDE THE DAMAGE POTENTIALAND FAILURE POTENTIAL OF EACH TREE IN QUESTION AND THE TARGET VALUE OF THE THREATENED ASSET (PEOPLEOR PROPERTY). CREWS WILL REMOVE ANY DEAD STANDING TREES THAT THREATEN PARK ROADS AND DEVELOPEDAREAS USING POWER SAWS AND OTHER RELATED TOOLS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN SAFER CONDITIONS THROUGHOUT THE DEVELOPED AREAS OF BRYCE CANYON. BYTHE END OF THIS PROJECT, ALL AREAS OF DEVELOPMENT (PARKING LOTS, OFFICIAL VIEWPOINTS, PLAZAS,AND BUILDINGS) WILL BE EVALUATED FOR POTENTIAL TREE HAZARDS. WHERE TREE HAZARDS HAVE BEENIDENTIFIED, THEY WILL BE PRIORITIZED FOR REMOVAL AND SUBSEQUENTLY REMOVED.BENEFICIARIES:THE PUBLIC AND STAFF WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT. THE PARKS DEVELOPED AREAS WILL BE SAFER PLACESFOR VISITORS AND EMPLOYEES.

THE RECIPIENT WILL UPDATE PROGRAM RECRUITMENT MATERIALS AND RECRUIT FOR SUMMER INTERNSHIP POSITIONS. THE RECIPIENT WILL PRESENT A QUALIFIED POOL OF APPLICANTS TO THE NPS FOR EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES COMPLETING PROJECTS PROPOSED BY PARKS/SITES AS ESTABLISHED DURING THE REQUEST FOR PROJECT PROPOSALS PROCESS. INTERNSHIP POSITIONS WILL BE LOCATED IN PARKS AND PROGRAMS ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND PROJECTS WILL VARY FROM PROVIDING FRONT LINE VISITOR SERVICES, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, DEVELOPING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, AND ASSISTING WITH PUBLIC OUTREACH.

THE INTERN WILL ASSIST WITH CURATORIAL ACTIVITIES SUCH AS OBJECT HANDLING, INVENTORY, AND GENERAL COLLECTIONS CARE FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF DECORATIVE ARTS, HISTORIC ARTIFACTS, AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL ARTIFACTS. INTERN WILL ALSO AID THE NPS ARCHIVIST IN THE PHYSICAL INVENTORY OF ARCHIVAL RECORDS COLLECTIONS, UPDATING ELECTRONIC CONTAINER LISTS AND FINDING AIDS, REHOUSING SOME COLLECTIONS, AND ASSISTING WITH REFERENCE AND RESEARCH REQUESTS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR A YOUTH INTERN TO GAIN PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, MONITORING AND RESTORATION. THE INTERN WILL PARTICIPATE IN ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION OF DAMAGED LANDS, INCLUDING CONDUCTING SURVEYS FOR IMPACTS TO NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES RELATED TO THE US-MEXICO BORDER AND FENCE REPAIR.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING: 1) MONITORING IMPACTS TO NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES RELATED TO THE US-MEXICO BORDER, 2) ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION; 3) ECOLOGICAL MONITORING OF AIR QUALITY, WILDLIFE, HYDROLOGY, POLLINATOR SPECIES, AND PLANTS; 4) AND INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1) MINIMUM OF 5 KM BORDER IMPACT TRANSECT SURVEYS; 2) WORK ON RESTORATION OF AT LEAST 5 SITES; 3) PARTICIPATE IN MINIMUM OF 10 RESOURCE SURVEYS; 4) REMOVE/TREAT AT LEAST 2 HA OF INVASIVE PLANTS.BENEFICIARIES: BENEFITS WILL BE TO YOUTH INTERN, WHO WILL GAIN CAREER SKILLS IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.

PURPOSE OF AWARD:THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) IN COLLABORATION WITH AMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE (ACE) WILL ESTABLISH A 7-PERSON YOUTH CONSERVATION CREW FOR 8 WEEKS THIS SUMMER AT CANAVERAL NATIONAL SEASHORE. ACE WILL WORK WITH NPS STAFF TO IDENTIFY AND COMPLETE PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE CANA VISITOR EXPERIENCE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO CAMPSITE MAINTENANCE, TRAIL REPAIRS, BEACH CLEANUPS, ASSISTING WITH SEA TURTLE PROTECTION, AND GENERAL PARK MAINTENANCE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:CLEAN-UP AND REHABILITATION OF FOURTEEN PRIMITIVE, BACKCOUNTRY ISLAND CAMPSITES.REHABILITATION OF VARIOUS TRAILS: CASTLE WINDY, TURTLE MOUND, AND ELDORA LOOP.MAINTENANCE OF BILL'S HILL BOUNDARY AREA.SHORELINE STABILIZATION AT TURTLE MOUND ARCHEOLOGICAL SITE AND THE DOCKS AT ELDORA AND SEMINOLE REST HISTORIC SITESASSIST WITH RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, MAINTENANCE, AND INTERPRETATION DIVISION SUPPORTBENEFICIARIES:CFDA 15.931 YOUTH AND VETERAN ORGANIZATIONS CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES.PRIVATE NON-PROFIT INSTITUTIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS; PUBLIC AND PRIVATE NON-PROFIT ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS; STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES; QUASI-PUBLIC NON-PROFIT INSTITUTIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT SUPPORT YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULT CAREER TRAINING AND DEVELOPMENT, AND EDUCATION IN THE AREAS OF NATURAL AND/OR CULTURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE UTAH CONSERVATION CORPS (UCC) WILL ASSIST IN THE RESTORATION OF ASPEN POPULATIONS TOIMPROVE WILDLIFE VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES FOR VISITORS. CREWS WILL COMPLETE PRESCRIBEDTREATMENTS IN SELECTED ASPEN STANDS TO REDUCE DENSITIES OF ENCROACHING CONIFER SPECIES, PROMOTEREGENERATION OF NEW ASPEN SUCKERS, AND PROTECT NEW ASPEN FROM BROWSING DAMAGE BYUNGULATES. TREATMENTS MAY INCLUDE MECHANICAL THINNING, UNGULATE BARRIER INSTALLATION, ANDSLASH PILING.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:RESTORATION ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE MECHANICAL THINNING USING POWER SAWS (IN NON-WILDERNESSAREAS) AND HANDSAWS (IN WILDERNESS AREAS) TO REDUCE THE DENSITIES OF ENCROACHING CONIFERSPECIES IN AND AROUND ASPEN STANDS. CREWS WILL BE REQUIRED TO FALL TREES UP TO 12 INCHES INDIAMETER AT BREAST HEIGHT (DBH). CREWS MAY ALSO BE REQUIRED TO BUCK AND LIMB LARGER DIAMETERTREES AND PILE SLASH INTO 6-FOOT X 6-FOOT BURN PILES TO BE BURNED IN THE WINTER MONTHS.DEPENDING ON PRESCRIPTIONS, CREWS WILL INSTALL UNGULATE BARRIERS USING LOGS AND SLASH PRODUCEDFROM THINNING AND COLLECTED FROM DEAD AND DOWNED WOOD.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED WILDLIFE VIEWING OF UNGULATES, BIRDS, AND OTHER WATCHABLEWILDLIFE THAT UTILIZE ASPEN FORESTS. CONIFER DENSITIES WILL BE REDUCED AND SURVIVORSHIP OF ASPENSAPLINGS WILL INCREASE AS A DIRECT RESULT OF THIS PROJECT. OVER TIME, ASPEN-RELATED DISEASEOCCURRENCE MAY DECREASE AS AN INDIRECT RESULT OF THIS PROJECT.BENEFICIARIES:THE VISITING PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PRESERVATION OF BRYCE CANYON'S DISAPPEARING ASPENPOPULATIONS. THIS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL HEALTH OF THE ECOSYSTEMS OF BRYCE CANYON ANDIMPROVE VISITOR EXPERIENCES BY CREATING WILDLIFE VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES
NPS-FY22-SER 2 - CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES BY YOUTH SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS - EC JOHNSON

COMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS PROVIDE TWO INTERNS TO WRITE SHORT SCRIPTS FOR LISTENING DEVICES FOR AN ACCESSIBLE TRAIL AT BIG THICKET. THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO PRODUCE 10 SCRIPTS FOR THE PUBLIC TO LISTEN TO AND FOR THE INTERNS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND VISITOR SERVICES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE INTERNS WILL LEARN ABOUT THE WETLANDS PINE SAVANNA ECOLOGY, INCLUDING PRESCRIBED BURNING THAT THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE USES TO ENCOURAGE LONG-LEAF PINE GROWTH. THEY WILL LEARN ABOUT THE BIG THICKET ECOSYSTEM BY GOING ON HIKES WITH THE INTERPRETATION DIVISION AND ASSISTING WITH RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROJECTS. THEY WILL TAKE THE KNOWLEDGE AND WRITE 10 SHORT SCRIPTS FOR LISTENING DEVICES THAT WILL BE INSTALLED ALONG THE SUNDEW TRAIL. THEY WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH PUBLIC PROGRAMS AND EVENTS HAPPENING AT BIG THICKET AND IN SOUTHEAST TEXAS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:OVER THE COURSE OF 12 WEEKS, THE INTERNS WILL WRITE 10 SCRIPTS FOR ASSISTED LISTENING DEVICES PLACED ON THE SUNDEW TRAIL. THEY WILL TAKE A TRAINING CLASS ON HOW TO WRITE FOR INTERPRETIVE MEDIA, ASSIST WITH PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND EVENTS, ASSIST WITH INTERPRETATION AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROJECTS AND WRITE SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS.BENEFICIARIES:APPROXIMATELY 16,000 PEOPLE USE THE SUNDEW TRAIL IN THE COURSE OF A YEAR. THIS PROJECT COULD BENEFIT ALL OF THOSE VISITORS, SINCE THE PRODUCT IS GOING TO BE AVAILABLE FOR EVERYONE USING THE TRAIL. UPON COMPLETION, USING SOCIAL MEDIA, BIG THICKET WILL HIGHLIGHT THE NEW ACCESSIBLE CONTENT, WHICH COULD RESULT IN A HIGHER NUMBER OF VISITORS TO THE TRAIL.

REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE UTAH CONSERVATION CORPS WILL HELP THE PARK MANAGE INVASIVE EXOTIC PLANT SPECIES ANDPROMOTE THE RESTORATION OF NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES. CREWS WILL REDUCE THE COVER OF INVASIVEEXOTIC SPECIES SEVERAL AREAS OF THE PARK, INCLUDING VISITOR USE AREAS AND BACKCOUNTRY SITES.CREWS WILL ALSO INCREASE THE HEALTH AND QUALITY OF VARIOUS VEGETATION COMMUNITIES IN THE PARKBY IMPLEMENTING RESTORATION ACTIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE UTAH CONSERVATION CORPS WILL ASSIST PARK STAFF IN NATURAL AREA REHABILITATION, WHICH WILLINCLUDE INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND PROMOTING THE RECOVERY AND HEALTH OF NATIVE PLANTCOMMUNITIES. CREWS WILL ASSIST PARK STAFF IN INVASIVE-EXOTIC PLANT REMOVAL THROUGH THE USE OFMECHANICAL, CHEMICAL, AND CULTURAL STRATEGIES. CREWS WILL ALSO HELP IN VARIOUS FOREST HEALTHIMPROVEMENT TASKS. THEY WILL REDUCE TREE AND SHRUB DENSITIES IN VARIOUS RESTORATION AREAS ANDASSIST IN TREE HEALTH PRESERVATION BY REMOVING INFECTED OR ATTACKED TREES FROM CAMPGROUNDS ANDRESIDENTIAL AREAS WHERE CURBING THE SPREAD OF DENSITY-DRIVEN INFECTION IS CRITICAL.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE REDUCED COVER OF INVASIVE SPECIES IN NATURAL AREAS OF THE PARK.THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO RESULT IN REDUCED FOREST HEALTH ISSUES IN BOTH NATURAL AND DEVELOPED AREAS.BENEFICIARIES:THE VISITING PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT BY EXPERIENCING BRYCE CANYON'S VEGETATIONAND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES IN A HEALTHIER, MORE NATURAL STATE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE UTAH CONSERVATION CORPS WILL HELP THE PARK IMPLEMENT RESTORATION AND IMPROVEMENTACTIVITIES TO INCREASE THE QUALITY OF HABITAT FOR THE FEDERALLY LISTED UTAH PRAIRIE DOG (CYNOMYSPARVIDENS).SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:CREWS WILL REDUCE THE COVER OF ENCROACHING SHRUBBY SPECIES AND INVASIVE EXOTIC SPECIES WITHINGRASSLAND MEADOW ECOSYSTEMS. CREWS WILL ALSO PLANT BENEFICIAL NATIVE SPECIES TO INCREASE THEDIVERSITY AND OVERALL COVER OF THOSE SPECIES WITHIN THE GRASSLAND ECOSYSTEM. CREWS WILL ASSISTPARK STAFF IN INVASIVE-EXOTIC PLANT REMOVAL THROUGH THE USE OF MECHANICAL, CHEMICAL, ANDCULTURAL STRATEGIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE IMPROVEMENT OF HABITAT QUALITY FOR THE UTAH PRAIRIE DOG BECAUSE OFINCREASED FORAGE AVAILABILITY AND IMPROVED PREDATOR DETECTION ABILITIES. PRAIRIE DOG POPULATIONSWILL BE MORE RESILIENT TO EXTRINSIC FACTORS THAT CAUSE POPULATION FLUCTUATIONS.BENEFICIARIES:THE FEDERALLY THREATENED UTAH PRAIRIE DOG WILL BENEFIT AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT. SINCE THE UTAHPRAIRIE DOG IS CONSIDERED A KEYSTONE SPECIES IN ITS ECOSYSTEM, MANY SPECIES WILL BENEFIT DIRECTLYAND INDIRECTLY AS A RESULT OF IMPROVED HABITAT.

REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HELP THE PARK RESTORE PONDEROSA PINE AND MIXED-CONIFER FORESTCOMMUNITIES BY IMPLEMENTING MECHANICAL TREATMENTS TO SUPPLEMENT MANAGED BURNS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:CREWS FROM THE AMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE WILL REDUCE PONDEROSA AND MIXED CONIFERSTAND DENSITIES PRIOR TO, AND AFTER, PRESCRIBED BURNS TO ENHANCE FIRE EFFECTS ON SMALLER DIAMETERTREES. CREWS WILL ALSO REMOVE LADDER FUELS TO PROTECT LARGER, OLDER TREES TO PRESERVE NATURAL AGESTRUCTURE OF FOREST STANDS. CREWS WILL MANAGE SLASH RESULTING FROM MECHANICAL THINNING TOPROTECT SHORT- AND LONG-TERM FOREST HEALTH BY PREVENTING PARASITE AND PATHOGEN OUTBREAKS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:RELATED TO THIS PROJECT IS A SEPARATE STUDY THAT WILL DETERMINE A RANGE OF ECOLOGICAL OBJECTIVES FORTHE PARK TO ACHIEVE AS A RESULT OF PONDEROSA PINE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FOLLOWTHOSE GUIDELINES AND THE RESULT WILL BE PONDEROSA FORESTS THAT ARE HEALTHIER AND MORE RESILIENT TODISTURBANCE SUCH AS DESTRUCTIVE FIRE, INSECT AND DISEASE ATTACK, AND INVASIVE SPECIES.BENEFICIARIES:THE VISITING PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT BY BEING ABLE TO EXPERIENCE FORESTS IN A MORE HEALTHY AND NATURALSTATE THAN CURRENT SITUATIONS. THE PARK WILL BENEFIT BECAUSE THE FOREST WHICH SURROUNDS ITSINFRASTRUCTURE WILL BE MORE RESISTANT TO DESTRUCTIVE WILDFIRE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PERFORMANCE GOAL - TO ENGAGE 7 YOUTH IN MEANINGFUL SERVICE PROJECTS FOR 43 WEEKS THAT PRESERVE AND PROTECT THE CULTURAL AND HISTORIC RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARKS OF BOSTON.PROJECT OBJECTIVES -PROVIDE TRAINING AND EDUCATION IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION PRACTICES FOR YOUTHCOMPLETE HIGH QUALITY, COST-EFFECTIVE PRESERVATION PROJECTS AT BOSTON NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK/THE CHARLESTOWN NAVY YARD AND BOSTON HARBOR ISLANDS NATIONAL AND STATE PARKMAKE RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP RELEVANT AND ACCESSIBLE TO THE YOUNGER GENERATION AND DEVELOP FUTURE LEADERS IN THE FIELD OF PRESERVATION AND CONSERVATIONSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:YOUTH PARTICIPANTS WILL COMPLETE HIGH QUALITY, COST-EFFECTIVE PRESERVATION PROJECTS AT TWO NATIONAL PARK UNITS (BOSTON NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK AND BOSTON HARBOR ISLANDS NATIONAL AND STATE PARK). RESOURCE PRESERVATION PROJECTS WILL BE IDENTIFIED AND GUIDED BY PARK STAFF AND SKILLED TECHNICAL EXPERTS. THE CORPS (7 YOUTH) WILL BE PROVIDED WITH SKILLS TRAINING ASSOCIATED WITH THE PRESERVATION PROJECT WORK AND A VARIETY OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR BOTH PERSONAL AND PROFESSIONAL GROWTH. THE CORPS WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED WITH THE SUPPLIES AND MATERIALS NEEDED TO COMPLETE PRESERVATION PROJECTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PROJECTS AT THE CHARLESTOWN NAVY YARD/BOSTON NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (BOST) WILL INCLUDE:REMOVE, REPAIR OR RECONSTRUCT, AND REINSTALL 8 WINDOWS (16 SASHES) FROM BUILDING 22REPAIR 400 SQUARE FEET OF HISTORIC BRICK PATIOS AND WALKWAYS BY REMOVING BRICK, REPLACING SUBSURFACE, LEVELING SUBSURFACE, RELAYING BRICKWORK, AND PERFORMING FINISHING WORKREPAIR AND PAINT 750 LINEAR FEET HISTORIC, CHARACTER DEFINING FEATURES (BOLLARDS, CHAINS, IRON FENCES)MANAGE VEGETATION (REMOVE INVASIVE PLANTS, PRUNE TREES AND SHRUBS) THROUGHOUT THE CHARLESTOWN NAVY YARD LANDSCAPEPROJECTS AT BOSTON HARBOR ISLANDS NATIONAL AND STATE PARK (BOHA) WILL INCLUDE:MAINTAIN 3000 LINEAR FEET OF TRAILS TO PROTECT HISTORIC STRUCTURES, VEGETATIVE BUFFERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE SYSTEMSREMOVE 20 CUBIC YARDS NON-NATIVE INVASIVE VEGETATIONMAINTAIN CONDITION OF 5 HISTORIC STRUCTURES.DOCUMENT, INVENTORY AND ASSESS LANDSCAPE FEATURES (CIRCULATION - PATHWAYS, TRAILS, HISTORIC ROADS, SIDEWALKS; VEGETATION - TREES, SHRUBS AND HERBACEOUS MATERIAL; BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES; AND SMALL-SCALE FEATURES) MONITOR NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE, INVASIVE VEGETATION CREATE TRAIL MAPS TO IMPROVE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCEDOCUMENT WORK USING GIS/GPS AND INTEGRATED INTO THE PARK RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DATABASEBENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT PROMOTES AND STIMULATES EDUCATION, JOB TRAINING, DEVELOPMENT OF RESPONSIBLE CITIZENSHIP, PRODUCTIVE COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT, AND MOTIVATES YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS TO BE INVOLVED WITH THE NATURAL, CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL RESOURCE PROTECTION OF THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BEYOND. ADDITIONALLY, IT FURTHERS THE UNDERSTANDING, APPRECIATION, AND CONSERVATION OF NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES BY PARK VISITORS, STUDENTS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE OBJECTIVES OF HOMESTEAD NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK'S (HOME) OBJECTIVE TO TELL THE STORIES OF EARLY AMERICAN WOMAN HOMESTEADERS. THIS PROJECT TELLS IMPORTANT STORIES OF FAMILIES, LIKE THAT OF THE CHRISTMAS SISTERS, WHO UPROOTED THEIR LIVES TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF HOMESTEAD PLOTS OFFERED UP UNDER THE HOMESTEAD ACT OF 1862. THIS PROJECT TELLS THE STORY IN DETAIL OF THE MANY STRUGGLES THESE WOMEN HOMESTEADERS ENCOUNTERED, THE VARIOUS WAY THEY ADAPTED AND OVERCAME CHALLENGES, AND HOW MANY OF THEM ACHIEVED ECONOMIC SUCCESS USING THEIR VARIOUS RESOURCES IN A VARIETY OF WAYS. THE RESULT OF THE INTERNSHIP AND ASSOCIATED WORK WILL ALLOW FOR HOME TO DISTRIBUTE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION SHARING THE STORY OF THESE EARLY WOMEN HOMESTEADS VIA WEBSITE, PAMPHLETS, POPUP AND LEGACY DISPLAY, AND THROUGH DIRECT ENGAGEMENT WITH THE PUBLIC. THE INTERN WILL ALSO PROVIDE INTERPRETATIVE SERVICES IN THE HOME VISITORS CENTER, DISTRIBUTE PAMPHLETS AND OTHER INFORMATIONAL MATERIAL, AND ASSIST IN THE JUNIOR RANGER PROGRAM. THE INTERN'S ASSISTANCE WITH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND INTERPRETATIVE SERVICES WILL ALLOW FOR HOME TO HAVE A FURTHER OUTREACH AND FROM BETTER SERVICE TO THE THOUSANDS OF VISITORS HOME HAS EACH YEAR.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:HISTORIANS HAVE CONDUCTED SCHOLARLY RESEARCH TO DEMONSTRATE THE STRONG CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THE HOMESTEAD ACT, WOMEN HOMESTEADERS, AND THE PASSAGE OF THE NINETEENTH AMENDMENT. THE INTERN WILL BE SHARING THIS IMPORTANT RESEARCH BY CREATING AND DEVELOPING RESOURCES THAT WILL HELP THE PUBLIC CONNECT TO THE HOMESTEADING STORY AS IT RELATES TO THE NINETEENTH AMENDMENT AND WOMEN HOMESTEADERS. THE INTERN WILL WORK FOR 10 - 12 WEEKS TO FURTHER COMPLETE RESEARCH ON WOMEN HOMESTEADERS, PERFORM VISITOR INTERPRETATIVE SERVICES AT PREDETERMINED LOCATIONS WITHIN THE PARK (VISITOR CENTER, WAYSIDE EXHIBITS, ETC.), AND TO DEVELOPING VARIOUS TYPES OF INTERPRETATIVE MEDIA TO INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF WOMAN HOMESTEADERS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE RESEARCH COMPLETED BY THE INTERN, AND THE PARK HISTORIAN WILL BE UTILIZED IN THE MANNER THAT PROMOTES PUBLIC INTERACTION VIA DIGITAL MEDIA (INTERNET), THROUGH PUBLICATION, AND THROUGH DIRECT VISITOR INTERACTION AT THE HOME VISITORS CENTER, SITES WITHIN THE PARK BOUNDARIES, AND WITHIN THE NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES. THIS AGREEMENT WILL ALSO PROMOTE AND STIMULATE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF AMERICA'S WOMEN HOMESTEADERS, PROVIDE JOB TRAINING FOR THE INTERN INVOLVED, AND PROMOTE A SHARED SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP AMONG THE PARTICIPANTS AND THE MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC WHO ARE PRIVY TO THE PROGRAMMING THAT IS PROVIDED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THERE IS AN INHERENT BENEFIT TO THE SCIENTIFIC AND RESEARCH COMMUNITY GAINED FROM THE FINDING OF RESEARCH CONDUCTED BY THE INTERN AND THE HOME HISTORIAN.BENEFICIARIES: AMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOALS OF THE PROJECTS ARE TO PROMOTE PUBLIC PURPOSES SUCH AS EDUCATION, JOB TRAINING, DEVELOPMENT OF RESPONSIBLE CITIZENSHIP, PRODUCTIVE COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT, YOUTH EXPERIENCE, AND FURTHERING THE APPRECIATION OF CULTURAL RESOURCES THROUGH THE INVOLVEMENT OF YOUTH IN THE CARE AND ENHANCEMENT OF PUBLIC RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL EDUCATE YOUTH AND GIVE THEM DIRECT TECHNICAL EXPERIENCE WITH HISTORIC PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES. THE YOUTH HIRED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WITH NPS RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS TO LEARN ABOUT PARK OPERATIONS, NPS MISSION, POLICIES, PROTOCOLS, AND PRESERVATION METHODOLOGIES FOR CULTURAL RESOURCES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE YOUTH THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPERIENCE AND TRAIN IN A VARIETY OF PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES INCLUDING BACKFILL PRESERVATION TREATMENTS IN GROUP I, GROUP II AND GROUP III OF TUZIGOOT PUEBLO. THIS INCLUDES ADDING ADDITIONAL CLEAN FILL MATERIAL TO MULTIPLE ROOMS TO MINIMIZE THE EFFECTS FROM DIFFERENTIAL FILL LEVELS AND UNDERMINED WALLS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE HISTORIC PRESERVATION TRAINING TO YOUTH IMPROVING THEIR APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF CULTURAL RESOURCES THROUGH WORKING WITH NPS RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS. THE PRESERVATION SKILLS LEARNED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL BE BENEFICIAL FOR FUTURE JOB OPPORTUNITIES. COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE THE SITE SAFER FOR VISITATION BY MITIGATING THE THREAT OF WALL COLLAPSE FROM UNDERMINED WALLS AND IMPROVE THE APPEARANCE OF THE SITE.BENEFICIARIES:THE BENEFICIARIES ARE YOUTH THAT PARTICIPATE IN THE PROJECT AND THE GENERAL VISITING PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PLACE COLLEGE-AGED INDIVIDUALS AND OTHER QUALIFIED PERSONS WHO VOLUNTEER THEIR SERVICES THROUGH CONSERVATION LEGACY IN EXCHANGE FOR TRAINING AND EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE IN VISITOR SERVICES. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AND STIMULATE WORK AND/OR EDUCATION AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUNG ADULTS THROUGH COLLABORATIVE PARTICIPATION IN VISITOR SERVICES AT MONTEZUMA CASTLE AND TUZIGOOT NATIONAL MONUMENTS IN ARIZONA.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE INTERN WILL CREATE ORIGINAL INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMING AT MONTEZUMA WELL FOCUSED ON BOTH NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING MAY INCLUDE FORMAL TALKS AND TOURS, TABLE DEMONSTRATIONS, SPECIAL EVENTS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS. THE INTERN WILL ALSO ASSIST PARK STAFF WITH CLASSROOM VISITS, FIELD TRIPS AND IN CREATING A JUNIOR RANGER PROGRAM AT MONTEZUMA WELL AND WILL SUPPORT COMMUNITY OUTREACH EVENTS SUCH AS FESTIVALS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE INTERN WILL FOCUS ON PUBLIC EDUCATION AND DEVELOP INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMING AS A WAY TO INCREASE STEWARDSHIP RATES AMONG VISITORS AND STUDENTS. THE INTERNS WILL BE PROVIDED TRAINING AND SHADOWING OPPORTUNITIES TO HELP FACILITATE FUTURE CAREER OPPORTUNITIES.BENEFICIARIES:THE BENEFICIARIES ARE YOUTH THAT PARTICIPATE IN THE PROJECT AND THE GENERAL VISITING PUBLIC.

YOUTH ENGAGEMENT IN YOSEMITE: RESTORE MERCED RIVER RIPARIAN AND MEADOW HABITAT
FY21 - IMR - CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES BY YOUTH SERVICE ORGANIZATION

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' SITKA NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK EMPLOYS SIX TO EIGHT RANGERS EACH SUMMER. HOWEVER, THE PARK'S RANGER PROGRAMS ARE NOT GEARED TOWARDS PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. THIS PROGRAM INVESTS IN CREATING PROGRAMS FOR LOCAL YOUTH IN CONJUNCTION WITH LOCAL SCHOOLS TO CREATE STRONG RELATIONSHIPS WITH THE NPS MISSION AND THE RESOURCES IT PROTECTS FOR OUR LOCAL STUDENTS. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES A YOUNG PROFESSIONAL THEIR INITIAL OR EARLY CAREER EXPERIENCE IN THE NPS ENVIRONMENT; AND PROVIDES THE PARK WITH INPUT FROM A NEWLY TRAINED PROFESSIONAL WITH UP-TO-DATE ACADEMIC EDUCATION AND TRAINING.

B.	PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT ARE TO SUPPORT AND STIMULATE WORK AND/OR EDUCATION AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUNG ADULTS THROUGH COLLABORATIVE PARTICIPATION IN SITKA NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK'S INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION DIVISION. THE INTERN WILL DEVELOP LEADERSHIP SKILLS AND PARTICIPATORY CITIZENSHIP VALUES WHILE CREATING EDUCATION PROGRAMMING FOR LOCAL SCHOOLS. THE INTERN WILL USE THESE DEVELOPED SKILLS TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF AND ACCESS TO PARK UNITS AND ENGAGE LOCAL YOUTH TO SITKA NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK  IN NEW WAYS.

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' THIS PROJECT WILL HELP KATMAI MEET THE NEED TO PROVIDE QUALITY EDUCATION PROGRAMING TO SCHOOLS ACROSS ALASKA AS STATED IN OUR 2009 LONG-RANGE INTERPRETIVE PLAN.  IT WILL MAKE THE PARK, ALONG WITH ITS RESOURCES AND STORIES, MORE ACCESSIBLE TO STUDENTS AND EDUCATORS DESPITE ITS REMOTE LOCATION, ENSURE THAT STUDENT EXPERIENCES ARE RELEVANT, INCLUSIVE, ACTIVE AND FUN, AND HELP ESTABLISH KATMAI AND THE NPS AS AN EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION AND STRENGTHEN PARKS AS PLACES OF LEARNING THAT TEACH SCIENTIFIC AND HISTORICAL LITERACY.

B.	PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT ARE TO ESTABLISH A CURRICULUM-BASED DISTANCE LEARNING PROGRAM FOR THE PARK.  WORKING IN THE DIVISION OF EDUCATION AND INTERPRETATION AND BASED OUT OF PARK HEADQUARTERS IN KING SALMON, ALASKA, THE INCUMBENT WILL HELP SHAPE THE FUTURE OF THE PARK'S EDUCATION PROGRAM BY DEVELOPING EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, CREATING LESSON PLANS, CONDUCTING PROGRAMS WITH STUDENTS VIA INTERACTIVE VIDEO CONFERENCING, AND EVALUATING THE NEW PROGRAM, MAKING MODIFICATIONS AS NEEDED .  THE CREATION OF THIS NEW PROGRAM WILL EXPAND STUDENT ACCESS TO PARK RESOURCES AND STORIES MAKING PROGRAMS AVAILABLE TO K-12 CLASSROOMS ACROSS AROUND ALASKA AND ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' THIS AGREEMENT SUPPORTS ONE (1) SCA INTERN FOR 26 WEEKS WORKING 40 HOURS PER WEEK. THE INTERN WILL ASSIST PARK RANGERS IN EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH PROGRAM, VISITOR SERVICES AT THE NORTHWEST ARCTIC HERITAGE CENTER, AND MEDIA PROJECTS RELATED TO WESTERN ARCTIC NATIONAL PARKLANDS.

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' THE SCA'S WILL WORK AS AN INTERPRETATION AND VISITOR SERVICES INTERN THAT DIRECTLY SERVES THE PUBLIC. AFTER TRAINING, THEY WILL PROVIDE INCREASED OUTREACH TO PARK VISITORS AROUND THE SIGNIFICANCE OF DENALI NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE, ITS DESIGNATED WILDERNESS AREAS, AND THE PARK'S NATURAL AND CULTURAL HISTORY.

B.	PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' THE INTERPRETATION INTERN WILL (1) BE INTRODUCED TO INTERPRETATION CAREERS INCLUDING INFORMAL VISITOR CONTACTS, INFORMAL DEMONSTRATIONS, AND FORMAL TALKS; (2) BE INTRODUCED TO INTERPRETATION CAREERS INCLUDING INFORMAL VISITOR CONTACTS, INFORMAL DEMONSTRATIONS, AND FORMAL TALKS; AND (3) DEVELOP AND DELIVER ONE OR MORE SHORT INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS THAT EFFECTIVELY FOSTER OPPORTUNITIES FOR VISITORS TO CONNECT WITH THE PARK AND IMPART ACCURATE PARK RESOURCE AND SAFETY INFORMATION TO VISITORS.

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

A. PROJECT GOALS ' 

THE GOAL OF HOSTING SUMMER SCA INTERNS AT THE DENALI NPS KENNELS IS TO TRAIN AND INSPIRE THE NEXT GENERATION OF DOG MUSHERS, ANIMAL HANDLERS AND PARK RANGERS. IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE AN INTAKE PROGRAM TO TRAIN YOUTH IN SPECIALIZED TRADITIONAL SKILLS IN THE PARK SERVICE IN ORDER TO CONTINUE THE LONG TRADITION OF RANGERS USING DOG TEAMS TO PROTECT AND PRESERVE THE UNIQUE NATURAL AND CULTURAL HISTORY OF DENALI NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE. IN ADDITION, INTERNS WILL HELP THE PARK BETTER SERVE SUMMER PARK VISITORS BY ASSISTING WITH PROVIDING PUBLIC ACCESS TO MEET AND LEARN ABOUT THE PARK'S DOG TEAMS AND WHY DENALI STILL USES SLED DOGS TO PERFORM WORK IN WINTER. INTERNS ENSURE THAT THE PARK'S SLED DOGS RECEIVE THE EXPECTED LEVEL OF DAILY CARE AND SOCIALIZATION, PHYSICAL EXERCISE AND MENTAL STIMULUS THAT THE PUBLIC EXPECTS IN A MODERN KENNEL. INTERNS ALSO ASSIST WITH ALL ASPECTS OF THREE FORMAL PRESENTATIONS TO THE PUBLIC EACH DAY INCLUDING SAFELY HOOKING UP AND DRIVING A DOG TEAM ON A WHEELED CART FOR DEMONSTRATION PURPOSES.  INTERNS ASSIST WITH OUTREACH EFFORTS ONLINE THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA AND WEBSITE UPDATES AS WELL. INTERNS WILL ASSIST WITH INSPIRING A STEWARDSHIP ETHIC FOR OUR PUBLIC LANDS. 

B. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' 

THE PARK WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON TRAINING ON INTERPRETATION SKILLS, PARK SAFETY AND LOGISTICS, AND THE NATURAL/CULTURAL HISTORY OF DENALI AT THE START OF THE INTERNSHIP. OPPORTUNITIES EXIST THROUGHOUT THE SEASON FOR ADDITIONAL, HANDS-ON TRAINING DEPENDING ON THE INTERN'S INTERESTS. THE INTERN IS ENCOURAGED TO EXPLORE THE PARK AND SURROUNDING PUBLIC LANDS AS A BETTER SOURCE OF AREA INFORMATION. OPPORTUNITIES MAY ALSO EXIST FOR WORKING WITH OTHER PARK DIVISIONS, INCLUDING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, IN ORDER TO LEARN MORE ABOUT POTENTIAL CAREERS.

THE PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE TRAVEL ON THE PARK ROAD OR OFF TRAIL IN THE BACKCOUNTRY. THE INTERN MAY BE BASED IN THE PARK'S BACKCOUNTRY OVERNIGHT OR BE TEMPORARILY ASSIGNED TO WORK AT ANOTHER DUTY STATION WITHIN THE PARK IN ORDER TO COMPLETE THEIR PROJECTS.  ALL TRAVEL WILL COMPLY WITH NPS TRAVEL PROTOCOLS AND WILL BE OF BENEFIT TO THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT. ALL IN PARK TRAVEL WILL COMPLY WITH NPS TRAVEL (NO-COST) PROTOCOLS AND WILL BE OF BENEFIT TO THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT. 

AS PART OF THE TRAINING AND EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE, THE INTERNS MAY ALSO BE ASKED TO TRAVEL TO CANTWELL, FAIRBANKS, ANCHORAGE, NIKOLAI, MCGRATH, EAGLE, WASILLA, WILLOW, EAGLE RIVER, OR OTHER LOCATIONS IN ALASKA TO PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING SESSIONS, ASSIST IN TRANSPORTING DOGS TO VETERINARY CLINICS IN EMERGENCY SITUATIONS, OR OTHER EXPERIENCES. ALL OUT OF PARK TRAVEL WILL COMPLY WITH NPS TRAVEL PROTOCOLS AND WILL BE OF BENEFIT TO THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT. 

OBJECTIVES 
THE KENNELS INTERN WILL:
1)   GAIN INTERPRETATION EXPERIENCE INCLUDING INFORMAL VISITOR CONTACTS AND A FORMAL PROGRAM INVOLVING A SLED DOG DEMONSTRATIONS.
2)   BECOME KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT AND COMFORTABLE WITH WORKING IN, AND INTERPRETING TO THE PUBLIC, THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE DENALI KENNELS AND THE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES FOUND IN DENALI NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE.
3)   DEVELOP PROFICIENCY IN THE FEEDING, CARE, AND TRAINING OF SLED DOGS INCLUDING BASIC CLICKER AND AGILITY TRAINING TO PROVIDE MENTAL STIMULUS AND PHYSICAL TRAINING FOR INJURY PREVENTION IN THE 'OFF SEASON'.
4)   HELP MAINTAIN A HIGH LEVEL OF SAFETY FOR THE VISITORS AND DOGS AT THE KENNELS.

FOR EACH OF THE ABOVE, THE INTERNS WILL BE TRAINED, EVALUATED AND RECEIVE COACHING THROUGHOUT THE SUMMER SEASON. 

UNMET NEEDS THIS POSITION ADDRESSES: 
1) INCREASE VISITOR SERVICES, SAFETY, AND SATISFACTION.
2) PROVIDE ESSENTIAL CARE, FEEDING, TRAINING AND EXERCISE OF SLED DOGS
3) INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR VISITOR APPRECIATION OF PARK RESOURCES, TRADITIONAL TOOLS AND CULTURAL HISTORY OF ALASKA.

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

A. PROJECT GOALS ' 

THE GOAL OF HOSTING WINTER SCA INTERNS AT THE DENALI NPS KENNELS IS TO TRAIN AND INSPIRE THE NEXT GENERATION OF DOG MUSHERS, ANIMAL HANDLERS AND PARK RANGERS. IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE AN INTAKE PROGRAM TO TRAIN YOUTH IN SPECIALIZED TRADITIONAL SKILLS IN THE PARK SERVICE IN ORDER TO CONTINUE THE LONG TRADITION OF RANGERS USING DOG TEAMS TO PROTECT AND PRESERVE THE UNIQUE NATURAL AND CULTURAL HISTORY OF DENALI NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE. IN ADDITION, INTERNS WILL HELP THE PARK BETTER SERVE WINTER VISITORS BY ASSISTING WITH INFORMATION AND ACCESS TO THE PARK'S BACKCOUNTRY IN WINTER AS WELL AS PROVIDING INTERPRETIVE AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR VISITORS TO UNDERSTAND THE PURPOSE AND SIGNIFICANCE OF DOG TEAMS IN DENALI. INTERNS WILL ASSIST WITH INSPIRING A STEWARDSHIP ETHIC FOR OUR PUBLIC LANDS. 

B. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' 

THE PROJECTS MAY INCLUDE EXTENDED MULTI-DAY OR MULTI- WEEK TRAVEL ON THE PARK ROAD OR OFF TRAIL IN THE BACKCOUNTRY. THE INTERN MAY BE TRAINED TO TRAVEL ON SKIS, SNOWSHOES, OR DOGSLED IN A VARIETY OF WINTER CONDITIONS AND TERRAIN THROUGHOUT THE PARK. THE INTERN MAY BE BASED IN THE PARK'S BACKCOUNTRY AND/ OR HISTORIC RANGER PATROL CABINS OVERNIGHT OR BE TEMPORARILY ASSIGNED TO WORK AT ANOTHER DUTY STATION WITHIN THE PARK IN ORDER TO COMPLETE THEIR PROJECTS. ALL IN PARK TRAVEL WILL COMPLY WITH NPS TRAVEL (NO-COST) PROTOCOLS AND WILL BE OF BENEFIT TO THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT. 

AS PART OF THE TRAINING AND EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE, THE INTERNS MAY ALSO BE ASKED TO TRAVEL TO CANTWELL, FAIRBANKS, ANCHORAGE, NIKOLAI, MCGRATH, EAGLE, WASILLA, WILLOW, EAGLE RIVER, OR OTHER LOCATIONS IN ALASKA TO PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING SESSIONS, ASSIST IN TRANSPORTING DOGS TO VETERINARY CLINICS IN EMERGENCY SITUATIONS, OR OTHER EXPERIENCES. ALL OUT OF PARK TRAVEL WILL COMPLY WITH NPS TRAVEL PROTOCOLS AND WILL BE OF BENEFIT TO THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT. 

OBJECTIVES 
THE KENNEL INTERNS WILL: 
1) GAIN EXPERIENCE WITH ALL ASPECTS OF SLED DOG CARE, FEEDING, TRAINING AND HANDLING. THESE TRADITIONAL SKILLS ARE RELEVANT TO A VARIETY OF ANIMAL CARETAKING AND HANDLING POSITIONS IN MANY RESOURCE PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION FOCUSED CAREERS 
2) GAIN TRAINING AND EXPERIENCE WITH WORKING IN, AND INTERPRETING TO THE PUBLIC, THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE DENALI KENNELS AND THE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES FOUND IN DENALI NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE. 
3) DEVELOP PROFICIENCY IN WINTER BACKCOUNTRY TRAVEL AND CAMPING BY DOG TEAM, SKIS, SNOWSHOES, AND OTHER MEANS OF WINTER TRAVEL. THE INTERN WILL RECEIVE EXTENSIVE TRAINING AND MENTORING FROM MORE EXPERIENCED STAFF IN RISK MANAGEMENT AND DECISION MAKING IN EXTREME WINTER CONDITIONS. 
FOR EACH OF THE ABOVE, THE INTERNS WILL BE TRAINED, EVALUATED AND RECEIVE COACHING THROUGHOUT THE WINTER SEASON. 

UNMET NEEDS THIS POSITION ADDRESSES:

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

PROJECT GOALS ' 
THIS TASK AGREEMENT SPECIFIES A PARTNERSHIP PROJECT BETWEEN THE NPS AND THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION WHICH INVOLVES PLACEMENT OF A YOUTH ASSOCIATE AT GATES OF THE ARCTIC NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE IN FAIRBANKS, ALASKA TO SUPPORT PARK SCIENCE, OUTREACH, AND STEWARDSHIP THROUGH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND FIELD WORK. THE PRIMARY FUNCTIONS OF THIS POSITION ARE TO ASSIST WITH FIELD BIOLOGY OUTREACH PROGRAMS RELATED TO ALASKA PARK SCIENCE, TO DEVELOP THE INTERN'S SKILLS IN WILDLIFE BIOLOGY, AND TO PRESERVE AND PROTECT THE NATURAL, CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL RESOURCES OF THESE PARKS.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' 
THE INTERN WILL PARTICIPATE IN A VARIETY OF FIELD BIOLOGY PROJECTS IN DIFFERENT PARKS TO DEVELOP AND ATTEND A VARIETY OF TRAININGS IN BACKCOUNTRY SAFETY, NPS MISSIONS, AND USEFUL SKILLS, SUCH AS MOTOR BOAT OPERATION AND WILDERNESS FIRST AID. THE INTERN MAY PARTICIPATE IN FIELD RESEARCH IN GATES OF THE ARCTIC NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE OR SMALL MAMMAL MONITORING IN DENALI NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE. IN ADDITION, THE INTERN WILL PARTICIPATE IN OUTREACH PROGRAMS IN GATEWAY COMMUNITIES (WHICH MAY INCLUDE CIRCLE, NENANA OR ANAKTUVUK PASS, ALASKA) AND LOCAL SCHOOLS THAT HIGHLIGHT THESE ALASKA PARK SCIENCE PROGRAMS.

PROJECT GOAL ' THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE DIVERSE LOCAL AUDIENCES RESOURCE EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES AND TO CREATE, PERPETUATE, AND OPERATE PROGRAMS MUTUALLY AGREED UPON RELATED TO WRANGELL ST. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK.

B.	PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE RECIPIENT IN FUNDING STAFF, TRANSPORTATION, SUPPLIES, AND EQUIPMENT FOR YOUTH EDUCATION PROGRAMS SUCH AS CHOSEN FROZEN (A MIDDLE SCHOOL CURRICULUM-BASED EXPERIENTIAL OUTDOOR PROGRAM), THE COPPER RIVER STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM (A SUMMER EXPERIENTIAL OUTDOOR EDUCATION PROGRAM), AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS EXECUTED IN THE COPPER RIVER BASIN.

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATE IN THIS PROGRAM WILL BE PROVIDED EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO LEARN ABOUT RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP AT A NATIONAL PARK. SPECIFICALLY, THE INTERN WILL LEARN ABOUT THE NATURAL AND CULTURAL HERITAGE OF SITKA NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. THE INTERN WILL BE INVOLVED WITH HANDS-ON PROJECTS THAT SUPPORT THE PARK'S NATURAL RESOURCES ACTIVITIES, WITH THE AIM OF IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF THE PARK'S NATURAL RESOURCE INTERPRETATION TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE INTENT OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO BUILD RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP ETHICS IN ITS PARTICIPANTS SO THEY MAY CONTINUE TO PROMOTE ECOLOGICAL CONSERVATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BEYOND.

B.	PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATE WILL LEARN THE FOLLOWING:

A.	THE BREADTH OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM ACTIVITIES IN A SMALL HISTORICAL PARK
B.	HOW TO CONDUCT NATURAL RESOURCE FIELD SAMPLING FOR A VARIETY OF RESOURCES, INCLUDING WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, SALMON SAMPLING, BAT ACOUSTICAL MONITORING, SOUNDSCAPE INVENTORY AND MONITORING, INTERTIDAL MONITORING, AND CONTAMINATE SAMPLING.
C.	THE PRINCIPLES OF GIS AND HOW TO USE LOCATIONAL DATA COLLECTION DEVICES (GPS).
D.	HOW TO ANALYZE DATA AND WRITE REPORTS USING NATURAL RESOURCES DATA.

ARTICE III ' PUBLIC PURPOSE
THE PROJECT PROVIDES INTERNS WITH A REAL AND MEANINGFUL EXPERIENCE IN WORKING FOR THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. YOUTH INTERNS WILL DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF NATIONAL PARKS. INTERNS WILL BE EXPOSED TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND ITS ETHICS IN THE PROTECTION OF THE NATION'S NATURAL, HISTORICAL, AND CULTURAL HERITAGE. BY PROVIDING INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS FOR THE PUBLIC, THE INTERN WILL EXPAND THEIR OWN LEARNING BY EXERCISING LEADERSHIP AND PUBLIC SPEAKING SKILLS. YOUTH WHO MIGHT NOT HAVE THE EXPERIENCE TO COMPETE FOR SEASONAL GS POSITIONS WILL HAVE AN OPPORTUNITY TO EXPERIENCE THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE FIRST HAND WITH A QUALIFIED MENTOR.

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' 
THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO EQUIP AND ENCOURAGE A YOUNG ADULT TO PURSUE A CAREER IN RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP EDUCATION BY PROVIDING RELEVANT WORK EXPERIENCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING. THIS TASK AGREEMENT SPECIFIES A PARTNERSHIP PROJECT BETWEEN THE NPS AND THE SCA AND ENTAILS PLACEMENT OF A YOUTH INTERN AT THE FAIRBANKS ALASKA PUBLIC LANDS INFORMATION CENTER (FAPLIC) TO PROMOTE PUBLIC LANDS AND RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP THROUGH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. THE INTERNSHIP SUPPORTS FREE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS RELATED TO SAFE AND RESPONSIBLE OUTDOOR RECREATION, NATURAL AND CULTURAL HISTORY OF ALASKA, AND LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCY CAREERS PATHS. FAPLIC PROGRAMS SERVE DIVERSE AUDIENCES FROM THE URBAN CENTER OF FAIRBANKS, ALASKA AND REMOTE ALASKA NATIVE VILLAGES.

' THE INTERN WILL LEARN AND APPLY EFFECTIVE PRACTICES IN CURRICULUM AND INSTRUCTION, INCLUDING HOW TO ADAPT LESSONS AND ACTIVITIES FOR DIVERSE AUDIENCES, BY ASSISTING THE FAPLIC LEAD EDUCATION SPECIALIST AND OTHER PARTNERS WITH OUTDOOR AND CLASSROOM-BASED EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOR KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE YOUTH.
' THE INTERN WILL GAIN OUTDOOR LEADERSHIP EXPERIENCE AND ABILITIES, INCLUDING AWARENESS OF BEST PRACTICES IN RISK MANAGEMENT, AGENCY POLICIES RELATED TO SAFETY AND COMMUNICATIONS, AND BUILDING AND MAINTAINING A COHESIVE TEAM DURING MULTI-DAY CAMPING-BASED EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN REMOTE LOCATIONS.
' THE INTERN WILL INCREASE AWARENESS OF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION CAREERS BY INTERACTING WITH NPS PERSONNEL REPRESENTING MULTIPLE DIVISIONS AND PROGRAMS AND COLLABORATING WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, AND TRIBAL, NON-PROFIT, AND UNIVERSITY ENTITIES ON MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL PROGRAMS.
' THE INTERN WILL BECOME AWARE OF NPS ORGANIZATION, MISSION, HISTORY, CULTURE, INITIATIVES, AND ACTIVITIES AT THE PROGRAM, PARK, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL LEVELS.
' THE INTERN WILL COMPLETE FORMAL TRAINING SESSIONS ON MULTIPLE RELEVANT TOPICS, POTENTIALLY INCLUDING NPS OPERATIONAL LEADERSHIP, BASIC FIRST AID/CPR/AED OR WILDERNESS FIRST AID/CPR/AED, BEAR AWARENESS, DEFENSIVE DRIVING, A-100 AVIATION SAFETY, INTERPRETATION TECHNIQUES, AND ORIENTATION TO ALASKA'S NATIONAL PARKS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS, NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND SITES OF INTEREST.
' THE INTERN'S SERVICES WILL ENHANCE THE REACH, RELEVANCE, AND EFFECTIVENESS OF FAPLIC'S INTERPRETIVE AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING BY DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTING TO THE SUCCESS OF THREE OR MORE MULTI-DAY SPECIAL SUMMER PROGRAMS AND ASSISTING WITH ROUTINE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES AS NEEDED.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' 
THE INTERN WILL PARTICIPATE IN A VARIETY OF OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND DEVELOP AND PRESENT A SCIENTIFIC POSTER AND VIDEO SHOWCASING A PARK SCIENCE ISSUE. THE SCIENTIFIC POSTER AND VIDEOS WILL HIGHLIGHT CURRENT PARK CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES, SUCH AS PLIGHT OF THE YELLOW-BILLED LOON AND THEIR DRAINING NESTING LAKES IN BERING LAND BRIDGE NATIONAL PRESERVE, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN INDUSTRIAL ROAD THROUGH GATES OF THE ARCTIC NATIONAL PRESERVE. OUTREACH PROGRAMS WILL TARGET GATEWAY COMMUNITIES SUCH AS CIRCLE, LOCATED JUST OUTSIDE OF YUKON-CHARLEY RIVERS NATIONAL PRESERVE. AND IT WILL ALSO INCLUDE SCHOOL PROGRAMS AROUND FAIRBANKS, SUCH AS PEARL CREEK SCHOOL STEM NIGHT, EFFIE KOKRINE AND UNIVERSITY PARK SCHOOLS' SCIENCE FAIRS, AND A VIDEOGRAPHY WORKSHOP WITH PARTICIPANTS FROM VARIOUS LOCAL SCHOOLS.

ARTICLE II ' PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES

A.	PROJECT GOALS ' THE SCA WILL PARTICIPATE IN EDUCATION PROGRAMS WITH KENAI FJORDS NATIONAL PARK (KEFJ) STAFF. THIS AGREEMENT SUPPORTS 1 INTERN FOR 24 WEEKS WORKING 40 HOURS PER WEEK.

B.	PROJECT OBJECTIVES ' THE SCA INTERN WILL HELP TO DEVELOP EDUCATION MATERIALS IN SUPPORT OF 40-50 PROGRAMS.  THESE MATERIALS WILL BE USED THIS YEAR AND ALSO IN FUTURE YEARS. THE SCOPE OF THE PROGRAMS IS BROAD AND INCLUDES ALL SCHOOL GRADE LEVELS AND ALSO ROAD SCHOLAR PROGRAMS FOR VISITING ADULTS.  THE EXPECTED TOTAL OUTREACH WILL BE IN THE RANGE OF 3000 STUDENTS AND ADULTS
